Pros: Beautiful artwork, great retelling of the Cinderella story, mutiple endings (and variants of them).

Cons: No voice acting, repetitive music, occasional issues with the text loading speed.

39096371.review:
Cinders est une adaptation en visual novel (une sorte de bd intéractive) du conte de Cendrillon.

[u]Histoire :[/u]

L'histoire prend la forme d'un vaste flash back. Cendrillon (Cinders) se demande comment elle en est arrivé là et se rappelle en se remémorant un principe au choix :  "Tout le monde mérite une seconde chance" ou bien "Chacun récolte ce qu'il a semé".
A partir de là, le jeu essaie de proposer une relcture plus mature de Cendrillon avec des personnages plus complexes. La marâtre est toujours aussi tyrannique, mais c'est aussi une femme qui tente de protéger sa famille de la ruine par tous les moyens. Les deux soeurs de Cendrillon ont une réelle personnalité et des côtes attachants. Le Prince est pris dans un dilemne. De nouveaux personnages sont ajoutés.
Tout cela permet à l'histoire de prendre diverses directions (même si cela reste assez linéaire) et amènera à 4 grandes fins alternatives (selon que Cinders parviendra à devenir reine, fuira, gagnera son idépendance ou mourra). Et chaque fin peut prendre diverses formes en fonction des personnages auxquels Cendrillon s'est attachée, de ses actions ou des traits de personnalité qu'elle a laissé apparaître.

Cet aspect-là du jeu est plutôt réussi.

[u]Dialogues et personnages :[/u]

Néanmoins, il faut bien avouer que les dialogues sont rarement passionnants. En effet, tout cela manque sérieusement de finesse. Les personnages passent leur temps à étaler leurs dilemnes moraux à haute voix, de manière très directe (on ne vous demandera pas de faire preuve de psychologie, c'est du tout cuit). Et les répliques énonçant des principes de psychologie de cuisine s'enchainent... Bref, on s'ennuie souvent dans les dialogues (sauf par moment avec le personnage de Sophia qui est d'un cynisme parfois piquant).

[u]Graphismes et animation :[/u]

Premier point, l'animation des personnages demeure très limitée (mais au pire pour un Visual Novel, ce n'est pas très grave).
Cependant, les graphismes ne brillent pas non plus par leur force : les fées manquent de féerie, la magnifique robe de soirée fait "téléfilm à petit budget", les décors sont d'un extrême banalité... Bref, il n'y a ni force, ni magie, ni tragique, ni véritable ambiance dans la forme.

CONCLUSION :

Tout cela fait que je m'étonne des critiques extrêmement positives de Kotaku, Indiegame et des joueurs. Ce n'est pas un mauvais jeu, mais il est terriblement oubliable.
J'ai été mille fois plus touché par les point-and-click de chez Daedalus ou par des visual novel comme Narcissus.

Alors comme le système d'évaluation est binaire, je vais mettre un pouce rouge (pour compenser un peu l'enthousiasme ambiant trop marqué), même si le jeu n'est pas abominable non plus. Juste très moyen.

Un wiki a été créé à propos du jeu à cette adresse : http://cinders.wikia.com/wiki/Cinders_Wiki

39032865.review:
I enjoyed this game quite a bit. Yes, it's a wee bit cheesy at times, and can definitely get a bit repetitive if you reach the point I did of being determined to get all the endings, but it's still very replayable and takes a looooong time to reach that point. It's basically a visual novel of a retelling of Cinderella, but with it's own twists on the story. The graphics are very pretty, and the overall art style is really enjoyable. While there's very little animation, because it's a visual novel you don't really expect much either. The story (and all it's variations) is very well done, and it's a lot of fun to try and figure out different endings, and how different actions impact things. Like I said, it can eventually get a bit repetitive, but only if you're at that point where you're just bound and determined to get those last few endings.

Now, that being said, once you've gotten all the endings and achievements, it's unlikely you'll play it again, or at least not for a good long while. This is the same experience I had with a different visual novel (based on Pride & Prejudice) I played elsewhere, however, so I sort of expected that once I finally completed everything. If you enjoy reading, making choices in books (sort of like a more interactive choose-your-own-adventure), fairy tale variations, or just visual novel type games, definitely buy this one. I would totally buy another visual novel from this developer, and sincerely hope they make more like this (with a different story, of course) in the future.

39016693.review:
Cinders is a great story-book game. It's a retelling , no, a reimagining of Cinderella,  withs beautiful drawings/graphics and a more meaningful story. The game has multiple endings and the dialogue in the game really make it shine. After finishing it, i HAD to recommend it to some of my friends, because it's not only a game filled with wit, but also a game that can teach you a lot about yourself.

The Game IS short and there isn't much autonomy (like i said earlier, it reminds me of one of those "chooser your own adventure" books), but that's not such a bad thing for it's price. 9/10

38953998.review:
I'm actually kinda mixed about this game but here's some pros and cons:
I liked how you can choose to befriend or alienate the stepmother and stepsisters. I expected this game to only let you befriend the dudes, but no you can improve your relationship with pretty much every named character. I also liked that none of the endings, in my opinion, were perfectly satisfying, because a lot of visual novels have stuff like "true endings" and this one doesn't. I also liked the art style... to a point, which I'll get to shortly.

Frankly, the writing style is kinda wonky. My main issue was with the dialogue. I'll be having a pretty casual conversation with my sisters one moment, and them suddenly I'm psychoanalyzing them and speak like a completely different person. This is especially noticeable when Cinders first speaks to the prince. They could have included the same subject matter without entirely changing Cinders' typical speech patterns. Also, I felt the dialogue gave way too much information a lot of times. Another issue was the design of the characters. They were kind of creepy looking... uncanny valley sorta? The prince suffered the most from this.

Overall, it was more enjoyable than not so I recommend it if it's on sale.

P.S. Perrault is a DILF

38871836.review:
Somehow a highly intelligent, socially fluid, doctorate-level philosopher finds herself under the thumb of an overbearing taskmistress stepmother whose power over Cinders, our protagonist, lies in the ability to not feed her if she doesn't clean up the mansion like she's supposed to.

Cinders injects agency into the on-rails plot of the fairytale narrative Cinderella by offering four major ending types and enough sub-endings to make it feel like you've gotten what you wanted - on the game's terms, of course. You have three romance options, only one of which is worthy of Cinders's hand. The conversations with Sophia and Gloria, the "evil stepsisters," are charming and at times vigorous rounds of badminton repartee. You can choose to warm up to either or both of them, as well as the opposite.

The events of the story play out like any soap opera would. You have a limited amount of freedom in choosing the order of the scenes and how they unfold. The dialogue is pleasant enough although the stylized "ruffian" speech of the top hat-wearing Obligatory Shady Person was a bit annoying to read through.

If I had my druthers, I would have left town with Sophia; I ended up leaving town on my own, thinking that this represented independence. The epilogue then presented me with an outcome that hand-waved away the panache with which Cinders had handled the entirety of the story. Apparently the independent ending requires you to administer a noble house as opposed to leaving a place that disliked you to start up your own life somewhere else.

I didn't buy the premise or the variable representations of Cinders's intelligence, but it's a nice little romp through the fairy-filled forest.

Overall, 7/10. Buy it on sale.

38852139.review:
Cinders – очень красивая визуальная новелла по мотивам «Золушки» на тему личной ответственности.

Счастливая и богатая жизнь Золушки обрела мрачные краски, когда у её отца появилась новая жена с двумя дочерьми. Теперь девушка ютится в подсобном помещении своего дома, где живут её мачеха леди Кармоса и сводные сёстры – София и Глория. Золушку ни во что не ставят и используют как бесплатную рабочую силу, хотя в доме полно слуг. Несчастная девушка и мечтать не может о том, чтобы пойти на бал, который принц устраивает в угоду почившему отцу, завещавшему сыну свой престол после того, как тот найдёт себе жену. Завязка полностью взята из сказки, но новые детали раскрывают её с интересных и неожиданных сторон.

Леди Кармоса – сильная независимая женщина, которая держит дочерей в ежовых рукавицах, объясняя свою даже не строгость, а жестокость тем, что без неё весь дом развалится и она желает для семьи только лучшего.

Глория во всём ей подражает и старается угодить, но без толку – мамаша всё равно недовольна. Со временем подобное поведение стало для Глории привычкой, ей не приходит в голову, что можно чего-то хотеть самой, а не быть обязанной хотеть с точки зрения матери.

София была для этих двоих козлом отпущения, пока не появилась Золушка. Суровое воспитание возымело на девушку отнюдь не то действие, что подразумевалось матерью: от своей жизни София ушла в книги, которые достаточно расширили её кругозор и словарный запас, чтобы научить едко отвечать родным. Когда от матери попадает кому-то другому, она лишь радуется, что в этот раз проблема обошла её стороной.

Что касается главной героини, то её черты формируются самим игроком: она может стать доброй или злой, мстительной или всепрощающей, одинокой или окружённой дорогими её сердцу людьми.

Принц – не единственный возможный кандидат на место спутника жизни Золушки. Следуя традициям визуальных новелл, Cinders представляет на выбор нескольких кавалеров. Если наскучит морализаторская сторона истории, можно с головой окунуться в романтику.

Впрочем, любовь здесь – лишь приятное дополнение. Личность и характер Золушки в итоге определяет не выбор партнёра, а сформированная в ходе повествования жизненная позиция. Стоит ли плыть по течению или жизнь следует взять в свои руки? В Cinders на выбор доступны оба варианта. На Золушку давят обстоятельства, которых для кого-то было бы достаточно, чтобы опустить руки, принять статус ни на что не годной девушки, навешиваемый на неё мачехой и сводными сёстрами, просто сидеть на месте и надеяться на что-то. В конце концов, как мы помним, в сказке надежда на чудо оправдалась: ей помогла крёстная фея. Чтобы совсем не лишать новеллу реалистичности и верного нравственного посыла, у этого выбора тоже есть определённые последствия.

Если по какой-то причине Cinders нельзя назвать лучшей в своём жанре, то она определённо высоко подняла планку качества визуальных новелл. В ней потрясающая графика и симпатичная анимация, несколько концовок, отличная музыка, книжные формулировки реплик и умные мысли, не говоря уже об оригинальном подходе к сюжету «Золушки», которую довольно сложно переосмыслить иначе, чем это уже было сделано множество раз другими людьми. Вариативность развития известной вдоль и поперёк истории приятно удивляет, персонажи радуют разнообразием и глубиной характеров.

Эта новелла обязательна к ознакомлению всем любителям жанра.

38768180.review: I like the art and I enjoy the story for the most part. However, as I played again and again to get all the achievements and find alternate endings, the characters kepts rubbing me the wrong way. Going through the game multiple times to discover how else Cinders' story could have ended become more of a chore than an experience, which is something I don't want to say about a game that almost requires you multiple playthroughs in order to get a better understanding of the characters and the story. 38578275.review:
Update: I played through almost all the routes once (I need to get [spoiler] the bad end and the poison end [/spoiler] to finish the game. 

I thought it would be fair, if I gave the game another chance, but the only thing that I can add, is that indeed, some parts of the story are very fairy tail-ish, but the writing didn't improve whatsoever. And I have to skip a lot of dialogue, when trying to go for another route because, like I said, the dialogue gets repetitive and I can almost remember the situations by heart now...

Positive aspect though: The main really changes personalities depending on the romance options. But sometimes I don't really get why. [spoiler] When she romances her childhood friend, she wants to sleep with him after their first date, which makes me really confused because it's pretty not realistic... but not like a fairy tail either... [/spoiler]

Original Review:

It was a really tough decision, but I can't recommend this game.

I think the fault doesn't lie in the game itself, but in it's rating - I think the game got pretty much overrated by people saying that this "is a new approach to the classic fairy tale with a lot of different paths to take". Also that "it's one of the best visual novels". One thing I can agree with is that the art is really stunning. It was something new to see a visual novel made in this style and I think it really fits the game.

Okay, now the not-so-great-things:

1) They said it's not like a fairy tale... well okay, maybe they didn't, but I thought they would at least change the plot slightly so that e.g. you don't have to go to the prince in every route. Also I thought it fairly discouraging that you can't choose a lot of things... [spoiler] There are 4 types of different endings, in which you can either die, you can travel away or you can marry the prince. Also there is no "happy end" so to say... Well it's okay that there isn't though, but... [/spoiler] Well, I pretty much think that it is still the fairy tale...

2) I felt that the plot was really rushed. You didn't have time to learn about the characters and you didn't have time to explore the environment. Also, I didn't quite like the pacing of the romance paths. The guard was a stranger to you, but you willingly chose to trust him [spoiler] even to travel with him [/spoiler]... And my, I think it's really naive... I wished there was more story... Also with the prince... [spoiler] why u go flirt with him, if you got another man waiting?? [/spoiler] 3) There was the feeling that they pretty much copy pasted, whenever they could, so at particular moments in the story the personality of the main and the other character just changes without reason....

Do you still want to buy this game?

Well, I'm not a jerk, so let's talk about the good points..

1) The art is really amazing, like I said.

2) The character are well done, expecially this is the reason, why I finished the game. Besides Cinders, who I found is a bit Mary Sue (idk, just my opinion), I really liked the description and the interaction with the other characters in the game. It is clearly visible that whoever wrote this, must have dealt with the human psyche a lot and succeeds in describing realistic characters, who are either nor good or bad and nor strong or weak. They have all their respectable opinions and struggle to live. My favorite was Sophia, who clearly shows that she can be a strong-willed woman, who has wits and who is trying to change her life little by little.


For my part, if you really want to play this game, buy it, when it's on sale. I got one route done in 3h, so I think it'll be 3-4h more to get everything else. 
And before you start judging: I DON'T THINK THE GAME IS BAD! I THINK THAT THE PEOPLE ARE TOO MUCH RECOMMENDING IT HERE, SO THAT YOU ARE DISSAPOINTED, WHEN ACTUALLY PLAYING IT!

38451294.review: Amazing game, I loved it. So much variation and excellent story and art!

38298950.review:
This game is marvelous and outstanding. The soundtrack pulls you in, the characters are fleshed out nicely, and the drama is real. A real spin on the familiar "Cinderella" troupe and makes you enjoy this difference, such as Cinders' equally bitter and cynical siblings, an iron fist stepmother, a childhood friend with a secret, a 'wise woman' who is headstrong and not afraid to show it and the captain of the guard that has honor issues.

While the game has it's high points, there are some problems with it too. One I found was how to find all the variations, you had to possibly start from the very beginning each time. Another is, while this is a game where your choices matter, sometimes the choices are limited and there are many variations per choice. Sometimes the sisters gave me headaches with their constant bickering and sometimes I disliked how Cinders would act in certain cases. Other than that, the game is well made. Its beautiful and all.

[spoiler] Perrault is best man, Tobias is a sad man, and the Prince romance makes no sense [/spoiler]

38213673.review: This is the only Cinderella-inspited visual novel you will need. This graphic style just like HOG game - which I love a lot. Character design definitely not my taste but I'm okay with that. The most beautiful girl in this game not Cinder but her step sis - Gloria. The story just not white and black side. Every character have their own reason and interesting side. I just love how MoaCube develop the step-sis/mom side, made them understandale and enjoyable. And Cinder, she doesn't the Mary Sue like the original story.

38090859.review:
I wasn't too keen on the fairytale setting but I really liked the format in which it was told and would like to see more. It's like reading a book but being able to interact within it and choose the outcomes. I wish all my favorite novels could be read and played like this!

My only concern here was that the ending I got was really disappointing as it pretty much went against all my choices in the narrative.

Specifically, [spoiler] I chose to try to bond as much as possible with the step-sisters and get on their good side, with the ultimate purpose of making our lives better by getting rid of the mother. I did not care for any of the romance options presented and thus avoided them. All this was good, right up until the end where the choices seemed neglected. I chose to poison the mother. And for some reason this resulted in Cinder essentially becoming her and ruling the house with an iron fist, meaning the sisters now hate her. And to pour salt upon injury the ending also resulted in Cinder being forced to marry, even though I explicitely worked against such ambitions in the narrative. Just, urgh... [/spoiler]

I don't know if this occurs with the alternative endings but I don't feel too inclined to try them. Still, it's a worthwhile experience on sale. Also, like said, I really want to see what they can do with another genre. Something completely different like space opera/sci-fi, apocalypse, or adventure.

37957026.review: This is a very enjoyable visual novel with good replayability value.  There were many points were I was genuinely and pleasantly surprised by the way events unfolded and the way I was able to relate to the principal characters.  The artwork was beautiful and the soundtrack (which I don't usually listen to) were beautiful and engaging.  Every choice felt like it had a direct and weighty influence on the story ending.  Now, this isn't to say the game is without flaws.  I do admit, the themes could have been handled more subtlely, the dialogue could seem unrealistic at times, and the plot could use a little more polish in some places.  As for the user interface, I wish I had the option of increasing the text size, and there is no way to completely get rid of flash effects, (though putting the dialogue on Instant mitagates some of them).  Still, the overall experience makes up for the issues I had.  It's a fun fairy tale adventure and worth the buy, especially if you can get it on sale.

37676724.review:
The artwork is stunning, the variety of choices nice, and the storyline is engaging. But after playing for a while I began to feel as if I was playing a preaching psychiatrist, not a teenage impoverished noble. Cinders' insights are rather amazing at times - as a teenager were you likely to understand why the school bully picked on you? - and her dialogue tended to become very "I know what is wrong with you, and if you listen to me, I will tell you how to fix yourself". At first I kind of thought it was interesting how fair Cinders was trying to be with her stepsisters. "We were both wrong and if we acknowledge that, we can start having a positive relationship" sounds great, but it starts feeling very out of place for the character and setting. Not to mention when Cinders isn't being wise, she is whining about her life. Not that she doesn't have some reason to whine, but it is disconcerting to jump from Wisdom to Whining. 

The other problem I had with the game, was that no matter what choices you make, you go to the ball. Even if it doesn't make any sense for what it is you want to do. And when you get there, no matter what has happened between you and your family, their scenes are always the same. Your scene with the prince is the only thing that changes, except you only have like three potential scenes with him, despite the multitude of endings available. 

I did quite enjoy the concept of the "Rewards" where you get little pictures added to the start screen depending on which endings you have unlocked.

Finally, the game always includes a perplexing scene between the shady figure and either the Fairy or the Witch (depending on which one you chose) that never really explains anything and seems to imply that any choice you make is not really the right one.

The game is excellently crafted, at once predictable and at once surprising with great dialouge and transitions. It's my all time favorite retelling of Cinderella. <3

37261236.review: Lovely game! Love the variety of independent female characters :)

36464309.review:
Cinders is a story-rich fantasy visual novel developed and published by MoaCube. A horrible stepmother and two unlikeable stepsisters...sounds familiar as it should because Cinders pays homage to "Cinderella", one of the most popular and beloved fairytales of all time. Cinders is a lovely young woman living out a quite mundane existence with her overbearing stepmother and two rude and constantly bickering stepsisters often wondering if life has something "more" in store for her. Tiring of the status quo of her current situation, she soon comes to a decision to make some changes...drastic changes that could possibly affect her entire life from this point forward forever. How will this fairytale end? This intriguing visual novel cleverly gives you the choices to shape Cinders personality while also determining how the story unfolds.

Visually, this title is beautiful with a palette of bright colors and fantastic lighting that also compliments the gorgeous artstyle which I'm happy to report is not anime inspired considering that most of the visual novels that I've read on Steam to date have been. The characters themselves are wonderfully animated in that their eyes and mouths move during dialogue and the facial expressions vary accordingly to mood. Something else of note about Cinders that I've yet to see in any other V.N. is the animation applied to static objects in the backgrounds. For example, if a scene is taking place in a house, the fireplace is ablaze with flame while outside the window you can see trees and shrubery fluttering in the wind. Likewise in town, you'll notice birds flying about overhead as the lanterns on lamposts are gently swaying to and fro from a light breeze flowing through. This use of animation on normally still objects like this really serves well to immerse you within the story so my compliments to the developers for applying this terrific mechanic to the V.N.. The U.I. in this title is also quite impressive whether you're selecting choices in game or options in the menu screens. The sound effect, colors and animation used on something as simple as the selection process just looks and sounds excellent with beautiful sparkle effects attached. Speaking of sound, the original soundtrack by Rob Westwood is absolutely fantastic in this visual novel. I have no doubt that you will find many of these tracks quite memorable like myself. In short, the outstanding graphical and aural presentation of Cinders very much compliments the wonderful narrative of this great visual novel. 

As "Cinderella" is one of my favorite fairytales I was extremely anxious to experience this unique take on the classic title. I very much enjoyed my read of Cinders from start to finish with it's compelling storyline and choices that actually matter and shape the narrative as you progress. I found myself connecting and really caring about what happens to her so it's always great when a V.N. can make you feel that way for a main character. I also thoroughly enjoyed many of the conversations between Cinders, her sisters and a few of the other N.P.C.'s in this title as they had some really thought provoking and hilarious dialogue. With over 120 decision points and multiple endings this visual novel has very high replayability. There are also a number of in-game trophies to be obtained but you'll have to discover for yourself how to unlock them as that is a total secret which is a nice additional feature. Option-wise, there are the basics for music, sound and text speed. There are a limited number of Steam Achievements to hunt down and Steam Trading Cards to collect as well. In conclusion, this V.N. takes a story that you've heard before and probably love but manages to add a unique and intriguing interactive spin to the narrative so Cinders is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to visual novel, fairytale and fantasy fans.

36185588.review:
If you like visual novels, you have to pick this one up! The art is gorgeous and the characters make you really engaged in the story (sometimes you just become infuriated with them, but that's how you know you've become invested in the outcome of the protagonist). Achievements are easy to get, if that matters to you, and it is highly replayable because there are so many variants on the endings! There's romance, betrayal, power to be had and  maybe even a little murder...the makings of a great drama! 

Highly recommend. I had it in my wishlist for years and almost bought it so many times, and I regret waiting so long to pick it up! It's almost always included in sales, so pick it up then for a good price (as I write this it is on sale for $6.79) if it seems too expensive to you right now.

36151792.review:
A surprisingly complex and original retake of the Cindarella story. It has a nice sense of humour -- although it is by no means hilarious -- and has a mildly philosophical approach. Choices are very complex and even early choices has a significant impact on the initial outcome.

I was also surprised by the number of endings the game had.

36003236.review: I'm 3 hours in (I think I'm nearing the end) and this is fantastic. Going in I was worried it would be too focused on romance, and don't get me wrong, romance is fun and all but I need something more gripping to get me attatched to a story, but luckily there's other elements to get me hooked. I love how this story has no "evil" characters, everyone has a reason for being who they are. All arounf great, although I haven't finished yet.

35427069.review:
Das ist kein Spiel! Im Verlaufe sind etwa 30 Entscheidungen zu treffen. Jeweils in der Art von Ja oder Nein. Nichts bewegendes. Und die Entscheidungen haben praktisch keinen Einfluss auf die Story. Hier und da mal einen kurzen Umweg aber das war es dann auch schon. Es gibt zwar vier Enden, doch die hängen kaum an den Entscheidungen im Verlaufe des Spiels. Ein, zwei sind es, die das beeinflussen. 
Dazu kommt die Technik. Der Sound ist langweilig und immer wieder unpassend, Sprachausgabe gibt es nicht, die Lautstärke ist nicht anpassbar, die Graphik ist statisch und oft einfallslos. 
Naja. Um etwas positives zu nennen: Die Achievements sind leicht zu erreichen.

35375645.review:
If you're a completionist looking for a light game with some quite beautiful art, this game is for you.

Some of the dialogue ignores your choices, specifically putting in negative responses or accusations, even if they make no sense given your choices and actions.

But other than that, and the occasional misplaced word, there weren't many downsides to this game.

It was fun, interesting, and definitely made me want to play it over and over again to get every little nuance right for each of the possible endings. I just played it for about 12 hours straight, and I'm only stopping because I'm too tired to stay up longer.

I've gotten all the achievements, and unlocked a lot of endings (but haven't gotten all 4 ending types to 100% discovered), and can't wait to get back into it when I get another chance for a long gaming session.

Not too predictable until your 5th play through or so, depending on what choices you make.

Very highly recommend.

35307253.review:
I was pretty hyped for the game, but despite how gorgeous it looked, I had a bit of an issue with the writing.
The characters might have been well put together, the way they expressed themselves was pretty off.
Especially with the amount of exposition we get dumped on us, it doesn't feel like it has a natural flow.
It was tiring to go through it, and have to deal with Cinders and the others trying to convince us how they had nothing at all to do with the original passive Cinderella story.

It's too bad, I really wanted to like it, but it's not for me.
The gorgeous art is gorgeous, music amazing, but a visual novel needs to prioritize their writing for me, first and foremost, and I'm sorry, I can't recommend this.

35230554.review:
Very conflicted about this game. I'll try to be as vague as possible to avoid potential spoilers.

Pro:

Beautiful
Imaginative
Branching story paths
Some moments of truly brilliant dialogue

The main 'con' that I have with the game is that a lot of the choices seem to give you some real freedom to choose your destiny, but the endgame is always the same. 'Go to the ____'. Okay; all of my other choices have been centered around fixing relationships and coming together, but the endgame has to be the same self-centered fairy tale despite everything I've done up to this point? I don't have the option to change anything, really. Relationships are repaired just for uncharacteristic (for the arc) behavior from Cinder.

I really, really loved this game at first. I liked a lot of the options, and seeing a classic story from a different perspective. But in the end, it really seems like they're trying to force you into the same too-small glass slipper, and it doesn't feel good at all. Fixable, but branches should branch; not wrap back around to the exact same dialogue as if characters still hated you.

35225294.review: Bought this game, the story is well-known and actually nothing special but for the reason you like an enjoyable novel with loving art you should buy and support the creators.

35156210.review:
A fun little visual novel that takes a more conniving approach to Cinderella. I enjoyed the contrast between the two 'Fairy Godmothers' and the balancing of the step-sister quite a bit. The backgrounds and colours were stunning and the story fun for a couple tries. As an achievement hunter I figured them all out in a day, but it took some exprimenting and save loads!

Things the game could benefit from:
A skip to new text button, or skip to choice (if there was one I couldn't find it)
Something about the EYES in the art were dead and creepy. The rest of the art is fine. The prince looked so very off.

35115441.review:
Based on the recommendations I was expecting something more like Long Live the Queen - a visual novel, but with RPG aspects and way more depth.

Nope, Cinders is just a visual novel, plain and simple.

It's a genre I'm not terribly interested in. But as far as it goes Cinders does have a fairly high production value: the music is good, the visuals are nice.

The core problem with it is that it's mostly a retelling of Cinderella. What little embelishments there are don't make up for that lack of originality. You already know the overall plot before it begins. And already knowing most of the story makes it very hard to care about anything that happens along the way.

I'd say Cinders is worth the time if you're super into visual novels, but everyone else can move along.

34865216.review:
A really beaufiful game. It's well-written, the art is beautiful and so are the characters and their minds. 
I haven't played the whole game yet, but so far, so good.

34714230.review:
Really worth your money!

I was in serach for an Otome that gave me an interesting (not too short) story, various options and for a decent price and this is exactly what I got from Cinders!
I've never played an Otome that gave me so many options and each of them lead you to a completely different path. Don't worry about the game being too short, if you want to play all the possible options it is going to take some time, I see this as a good thing because it means you won't get bored of this game so soon for there are so many things to discover and so many tangibles!
The artwork of this game is completely beautiful! the characters, the backgrounds, even the dialogue box, you can see the artists put so much effort in this.
Soundtrack is also really good and really knows how to set the player in the mood.
The story itself is really good and besides choosing a partner you can also choose your main goal in the story! There are 4 different endings and each has it's own variables. I love how you can change your relationship with everyone of the charcaters beside the possible suitors! (Btw Tobias is my favorite one, he's a cutie)
Cinders is a really enjoyable and exciting visual novel and I reccomend it for all types of Otome fans!

34395697.review:
One of the better done "choices matter" visual novels. Definite 9/10

tl;dr:
... If you don't want to read, it is not for you.


It's a nice take on the classic fairy tale -- where you can actually go the route the Cinderella fairy tale is, or get it completely differently.

It has a great replay value because not only can it unfold differently, but some routes completely change the other characters, from the cliche 2D cardboard fairy tale stereotypic characters to believable people with their own motivations, conflicts and issues.

It is also very nicely drawn, with most of the game being done in full shaded style, interspersed with book-like monocromatic character introductions and finale.

There are a few imperfections, of course, some of which could have been easily avoided.

Most importantly, there is a significant continuity goof in the main storyline that would have made infinitely more sense if two major plot elements were placed in reverse order (getting money before having the reason to).

There are a few minor ones, e.g., even when given the carte blanche to act by Carmosa, you still hide from her -- which was definitely just due to reuse of existing scenes.

The indicator that some [part of the] scene is choice-dependant is a good idea, but unfortunately, it does not work any well simply because the majority of content is choice-dependant. It is essentially the reverse -- showing you the very few points you are going to go through anyway, no matter what you do.

Some of the endings (including all bad endings) are not just harder to get than perfect endings, but are so obscure you need to either use a guide or note down the complete choice tree to have a chance of getting them.

Another minor gripe is that character introduction screens just flash up but don't have any details, nor are accessible as collectibles from the "Rewards" screen or serve any other function.

34057687.review:
If you're looking for a simple visual novel take on the cinderella story, you've found it.
While you won't get a ton of hours out of it, it is definitely worth multiple playthroughs just from sheer curiosity of the many branches the story can take. 

The story and different choices are well written, although some of the characters can be pretty predictable.

If you're looking for actual gameplay, the visual novel tag is probably not your best bet. ;)

34047721.review: I honestly don't get tired of this game. I've played through a few times to get different endings and I'm still finding it enjoyable. The writing is clever and has made me laugh out loud several times. Definitely recommend for fans of visual novels. Your choices actually change the story in a noticeable way. Great game.

33707125.review: Very artistic and the sound track is brilliant! It goes to show that induie games are on the rise now and with all the different endings you can get def worth getting! :)

33649104.review:
Basically Cinderella the Visual Novel. Except, being a VN, you are allowed to make choices that lead to various other results (like... MURDER!). But in an overall sense, it's a short VN with pretty art and is competently made. I've seen better VN's, of course, but I have seen far worse ones as well. This one at least managed to keep me interested, and then allowed me to complete it shortly before my interest may have begun to wane. In other words... I remained interested and engaged throughout the story being told. And that is, ultimately, what VN's and games in general should do their best to succeed at.

So... I guess this is a pretty good one. Short, but not something I regret playing :o

33441548.review: Fun but short game with multiple endings that are influence with each situation/dialogue choice you make. Pretty graphics and pleasing sound effects.

33409060.review: Beautiful game.  Story is good.  I really like taking tropes and using them with a twist.  This is what this game does.  Lots of choices, all of which modify the game in some way, even if it's just increasing a hidden value to determine things.

33256271.review:
I really enjoyed this game! The play through isn't too long, so it's easy to try all the different choices you have through out the game and see all the different endings. I have so much through going through and seeing how each of your choices changes the ending. A fun twist on Cinderella. 

My only complaint is I wish I had the option not to have text scroll on screen and the box can't just pop with all the text in it, it has to scroll across. Otherwise, I recommend it for any one who enjoys VNs, Fairy tails, and choice matters games.

33175335.review:
This game blew my mind with its spectacular artwork and music! I thoroughly enjoyed playing through it for the sole purpose of unlocking new scenes and listening to more soundtracks! 
The storyline is a cliche, I admit, but it is based on the story of Cinderella so that's expected. There are few twists and dark elements which make up for the cheesiness, though. And you get to choose who you end up with, so that's a bonus.
All in all, I think this game is perfect for those who appreciate art and music more than engaging storylines. And the price is acceptable when it is on sale.

33043261.review: Beautiful artwork, great game all around.

33035342.review:
Cinders is a really great interactive Visual Novel based on the famous Cinderella fairytale. You develop the story from her perspective and can try to help her reach her goals with some clever decision making!

The [b]positive highlights[/b] of Cinders include:
[list]
    [*] very beautiful, artistic drawings
    [*] the soundtrack creates both tension and perfectly invokes the fairytale-mood
    [*] creatively designed characters are far from being one-dimensional: they show different facets, nobody is purely good or evil
    [*] well written dialogue with many options and choices which influence the story
    [*] interesting and very diverse endings which make multiple playthroughs enjoyable
    [*] the prince is not the only romance option (!)
    [*] handy skip-function for already read dialogue
    [*] branch-symbol that appears whereever the storyline could differ
    [*] for achievement hunters: 100% are doable in an easy 4 hours
[/list]

Overall I can say that the game is simply beautiful. For fans of the genre it's a must-buy. For every sceptic it's definitely worth a try.
I had an amazing time playing Cinders and can only recommend it.

[b]10/10[/b]

32976621.review: It's a pretty nice visual novel with a good cold open.  Replaying is a little tedious, but the writing is pretty solid and the art is gorgeous.

32919839.review: MAQUIAVELLIC QUEEN ON THE FIRST TRY YEAAAAH

32884367.review: Were you one of those people who would keep a finger on the choice page while reading Choose Your Own Adventure books? God forbid you make a wrong decision! Well, you can't do that here! It's the story of Cinderella, which we all know, and every decision you make only expands the possibilities. The artwork is beautiful, in fact has given me inspirations for cosplay/costumes. All the many decisions and choices gives the game replayability. The only tough part I had (which wasn't really that tough) was navigating the different areas. Overall this is a cute game, and if you still like fairytales, Is a good addition to your library for a lazy afternoon.

32861154.review: Une autre manière de voir le conte de Cendrillon, avec bien plus de possibilités et de choix : la "bonne fin" n'est peut-être pas celle que l'on croit...

32849021.review: This game is one of the best games that I have ever played. The main character is very interesting and sassy. The art is beautiful and unique. The music is great and the character inteactions are natural and fun.The story is very well written and balanced : serious where it needs to be and funny when it's necesssary. What I especially LOVE about this game is that, unlike many games that have a set "game path" despite what choices you make or has limited endings, the choices in Cinders give you entirely different endings : there are so many variables to the endings in the story and the heroine's personality changes according to the choices you make along the story so that the ending makes sense. In short, it's a great game and I'd buy it with or without sale because I believe it deserves all the support we could give it. I would defnitly be interested in more games similar to Cinders from the game makers.

32824739.review:
Thoroughly enjoyable! 

The "new take on a classic fairytale"-trope might not be exactly new but I really enjoyed how it was executed in Cinders. 
It's like being told a bedtime story, not liking how it ends so you spend the next hour trying to convince your (tired) parent who really just wants you to GO TO SLEEP that "If she just did this thing, it could have turned out even better!  !". (Any resemblance to actual events is purely coincidental) In Cinders you get to do just that under the guidance of the branching system. 

Ever thought the story would be so much nicer if the sister all just got along? 
You can make it happen.

Being the queen to some dude you danced with for literally 5 minutes never really appealed to you all that much? 
DON*T be the queen! (or BE the queen and have that prince guy do your bidding! Who's gonna stop you?) 

Would you just solve all the fairytale problems with fairies, as the higher powers intended?
Boy, do I have news for you.

TL;DR: Get the game, it's fun.

32750680.review: It's pretty much the best take on Cinderella since sliced bread. Very deep, troubled characters from an abusive family, frilly victorian art style, moral and normal choices that will break your heart. Deals with themes of freedom and responsibility. Been a while since I played it, but yeah, much more than I expected and should entice anybody to look up the writer's other games.

32736519.review:
This is probably one of the better retellings of Cinderella, and one of the better choice and consequence games I have played. It emphasizes that your chooices do make a differeance well not shoving it down your thoart or making you feel guilty when you make a "evil" or "bad" decision. Each character as their own voice and you and tell them apart by dialog thee sisters are sympathic And they make you understand the motivation of the step mother well still not condoning her actions. 
Though Cinders as a character herself is one of the weaker ones I think this is simply because of her roll She's too much personality to totally put yourself in her shoes but compared to the sisters, the mother, as well as Perrault and Madame Ghede she is diffently in the weaker tier. 
As for the art. The backgrounds a lovely but the human characters too me a bit to get used to. The lip animations creeped me out and the eyes and lips have very strange propotions, and to me it seems everyone's arms are a bit short. Not to mentions some of the poses are a bit awkward. This is more of a personal taste but I would have liked the art a bit better if they had kept with the style in the title screen a bit more simple and elegant looking.
Finally for me these games don't have a tone of replay value. Though I will say none of the ends I got so far could be defined as "Good" or "Bad" They both have a little bit of each in them which is nice. But I am totallly not intrested in any of the queen endings. Because like Cinders, the Prince is in the weaker teir. And I was happy with the endings I got. And There is little reward for getting all the variations. So again almost no replay value. 
But all in all it is amoung of the top of the visual novels.

32574858.review:
I'll get right down to it: this game really doesn't have much going for it beyond novelty. Once you get past it being a western-made visual novel that doesn't have an anime artstyle, it's not really anything that hasn't been done better. The concept of a classic fairy tale with in-depth characters and new complexities has been done dozens of times and in more interesting ways to boot.
For starters, the characters: I like Sophia and the prince is an interesting take you don't see often (someone who is trying to create complete social reform with a lot of ambition but isn't portrayed as evil is oddly not portrayed often in media). Everyone else.....eh. The love interests that aren't the prince feel like they were put there for the sake of having more than one love interest. Gloria is failry generic. Carmosa really doesn't feel all that deep despite the game constantly telling me that there's more to her than meets the eye. Cinders feels like an attempt at having a capable female protagonist that remains feminine, but her only really strong and independant trait is that she isn't ever captured (meanwhile there are other similar female protagonists in visual novels, such as Code: Realize's Cardia, who manage to be portrayed as feminine but capable in spite of them being subjected to classic damsel-in-distress tropes). Everyone else ranges from meh to okay.
The art is...good? It is clearly done in a skillful manner, but something about it just feels uncanny valley, such as the way the eyes soullessly move back and fourth.
The music is honestly pretty forgettable.
But by far the worst trait about this game that makes me not recommend it is the endings. There are four endings, but there are numerous variations within those four endings. If you want to have every variation unlocked, you have to play the game all the way through 17 times at minimum (and if you don't use a guide, I could very easily see that number nearly doubling). And while that is a lot, it would be tolerable if it weren't for the fact that, aside from minor dialogue changes and the order some scenes happen, they all feel nearly identical. I got about 50% variation on all four endings before I decided to call it quits. And the worst part? You. Get. Nothing. For. Doing. It. There are only eight Steam Achievements in the game, for all eight in game rewards, none of which require you to get every ending variation.
So, in conclusion, this game has little to no value that isn't novelty. Would only recommend it if you got it for free, and even then, only if you don't care about 100% completion.

32402962.review:
Я повёлся на красивую рисовку и обещания мрачной и взрослой интерпретации истории про Золушку, но всё, что я получил - это кучу деpьма в лицо.
От настолько унылых диалогов и такого тяжёлого скучного текста хочется придушить ту мpазь, которая всё это написала голыми, blyad, руками.
Таланта у того, кто писал текст - ноль, литературный язык - никакой. За наглую попытку выехать за счёт лживых обещаний по всем нам известной сказке хочется пинать тваpь ногами в лицо.
Надеюсь он захлебнётся собственной блевотой от собственного текста.
Таким урукам не место на этой планете, они отравляют жизнь всего человечества подобным текстом. Ей богу, как будто диплом какого-нибудь бакалавра читаешь. Из-за таких уpодов люди и ненавидят чтение.

32380764.review: This game is so beautiful and enjoyable. The music and art are fantastic, and the multiple incarnations of the classic cinderella story were so fun to explore and find.

32329911.review: Cinders is one of the few games I have completed and taken the time to get all of the acievements for. It is beautifully designed and is a mature take on the story of Cinderella. There are many endings, and subtle variations that are fun to pursue. I would highly recommend this game, it is just beautiful.

32184836.review: Wonderful game! Its a more grown up version of Cinderella which I appreciate. Once I figured out that control is the skip button it was great! Looking forward to playing more great games from them!

32014139.review:
I enjoyed this title. Especially the art and musical cues and such. It was a bit stiff at points but it was still engaging and fun to read. 

I would've liked a path where the household all finally got along but given the nature of how grim they made that idea sound, I get why that was never going to be an option. Still though, there were moments of hope and certain choices that I felt would've been natural to write a blurb at end game about how in time they all sort've out their shit and got along swimmingly. 

As for the men on this game... Perrault forever! I felt he was the most interesting of the 3. Tobias was just vapid and boring and the Prince was just... a Prince with a little more political inclinations in his noggin. They didn't feel like they had enough substance for me to get involved with so my first playthrough I glazed right over them. 

But aside from that, I felt it was written well enough for me to get all the endings and achievements. So. Yes. It's a decent VN I recommend you read.

31847008.review: A charming little visual novel that actually takes your choices and forms your character around them. Multiple endings, each requiring a different approach to how you view the world.

31844902.review: I played more than a few times just to score all the guys. <3

31818578.review:
Habe "Cinders" noch nicht ganz durchgespielt, weil man halt doch immer wieder mal im Wörterbuch nachschauen muss, wenn man im Englischen nicht so sattelfest ist. 
Aber es liegt wohl auch daran, dass man einfach mal verweilen und die Atmosphäre auf sich wirken lassen möchte: Das Spiel des Lichts zwischen den Bäumen und auf dem Wasser, die Schönheit einiger weiblicher Gestalten...
Ich möchte an dieser Stelle jetzt nur auf die Grafik eingehen, weil sie mir so herausragend erscheint.
Ich bilde mir schon ein, von Kunst etwas zu verstehen, und würde sagen - selbst wenn man berücksichtigt, dass mit den ganzen Computerprogrammen, die jetzt verfügbar sind, es sicher viel leichter ist, gewisse Effekte zu erzielen als etwa zur Zeit von C. D. Friedrich mit Pinsel und Leinwand - das künstlerische Niveau, das die polnischen Entwickler(innen) hier präsentieren, ist schon bemerkenswert!
Ich denke, wer sich einen Sinn für den Zauber alter Märchen und Sagen bewahrt hat, wird von dieser VN nicht enttäuscht sein.

31781747.review: Great art and lovely music, but what I liked most was I have to say this game caught me pleasently off guard at the conclusion.  I had a slight inkiling that the direction I was raking wasn't ideal for rulership, but when the game branded my choices as producing a loveless evil queen who inspired a bloody revolution, I was taken aback.  I thought I was making clever choices, but I guess my choices were too clever?  Anyway, there are a vast array of endings and it only takes about 4.5 hours to play through, so I'll definitely be playing again.  If there's one thing I would change, it's the prologue.  It sets up a point in time that the player knows is coming and can't change.  I would take it out, but this game has been out for awhile now, so I guess it won't change.  It's not damning, I just will be skipping it each time in the future.

31750153.review:
I remember the first time I saw this game, I was like "this is so expensive! There's so many games like this in a more affordable price! Why should I buy this one?". But then, I saw a review saying that yeah, it was expensive but it was really worth the price and a truly great game and I got curious. 

I brought it and honestly, I loved it. The story, the characters, the beautiful, beautiful art. Not to mention the fact that the game helps you to know which events are a a consequence of a previous choice which is really good for this sort of game. 

I like the fact that the ending is actually a bunch of possible endings for different aspects of the story combined but sometimes, they don't make a lot of sense based on your choices. Even if you become bffs with one of the sisters, if you don't get the right ending, it will say that you guys ignored each other and hated each other and all that. It's really a pain. 

Anyway, yeah, this game is pretty cool if you like heavy story-based sort of games and not necessarily for its romance but more for the story of a independent and interesting female protag.

31689746.review: Played with my wife - we both really enjoyed it! Great atmosphere and characters!

31641000.review:
The art is gorgeous. The music is lovely. The rest, well...

As a VN, this isn't as intensive a game play as anything with stats or more choices; it's basically a choose-your-own-adventure but instead of adventure, we have magic and personal relationships. 

The problem is that the personal relationships are uninspiring in the romance category, and just about impossible to navigate in the family category.  You can be the nicest or toughest you want, the novel railroads you to a conclusion with regard to your stepmom and stepsisters. Are they well-written, well-rounded, kind of interesting? Sure. They're also massively frustrating, and the option to just leave town and join the army is not available (sadly).  The possible romantic guy leads all have one fatal flaw that make them impossible to sympathize with (well, one of them is very nice. And boring). 

So, yes, if you just want to enjoy the visuals, get this on sale. It won't disappoint, although there's practically no movement-- it's a gorgeous fairy-tale picture book. But do not expect plot, dialogue, or character development to make any sense at all.

I'm not very impressed with this game and while parts are nice or ok, I think the story and characters - something visual novels rely on a great deal - are very poor. The art is quite nice, music is nice but gets repetitive quickly, the dialogue works at times but has a lot of bad moments and repeats a lot of things unnecessarily for example. The story seems to be trying to push this "strong independent woman" theme in such a ham-fisted way I cringed, it's laughably badly written in parts and there is nothing subtle from characterization to foreshadowing and plot.

The characters aren't conceptually bad, but end up unlikable and uninteresting in how they are used and, primarily, how they are written with dialogue that makes them entirely 2 dimensional. The choices you make for the main character don't seem like her choices but something someone is forcing her to do. I don't play a lot of visual novels but I've played some in the past and don't have anything against them, in fact liking some a lot (like Steins;Gate and Katawa Shoujo). This is not one of them and I do not recommend you play this unless you like being told what is right and how you should live your life by almost every character in an extremely preachy way - and what they preach is not exactly morally justifiable even; other reviews detail how the game consistently tells the player/main character that the abuser (the stepmother) is in the right and you should feel bad for wanting to rebel against her and take the house that is legally yours.

To clarify on my play length, I stopped playing after an hour and looked up videos to see if it got better, and from the conversations and scenes that I saw, it got worse so I didn't return.

31188243.review:
This is a lovely little game. Well, it's not really a game - more an interactive story. You click through listening to dialogue between the main characters and Cinders' thoughts, and, like a "Choose your own Adventure" novel, make choices at key points. That's pretty much it, as far as action is concerned.

But it's such a nice experience that it doesn't matter. The dialogue seems a bit trite to begin with (and to be fair, is a bit stilted at times, with the odd sentence that sounds like it's been badly translated) but you soon grow to like it, and the story can go in one of several directions based on your choices. There aren't that many backdrops or characters altogether, but the art and music are so wonderful that it's really a pleasure to play through.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this; it's just such a nice experience. Don't buy it, though, if you're expecting action, or puzzles, or a game - it isn't really any of those things. It's more like you're in the audience for a mysterious and beautiful piece of theatre that makes you feel like a little child listening to a storyteller.

30917070.review:
Ce jeu n'est autre qu'une histoire visuelle où vos décisions impactent sur son déroulement. N'attendez pas plus que de vous laisser porter dans l'univers par la lecture et la curiosité.

Tout commence par une fatalité : "Rien ne sera plus pareil..." à la suite du quoi on remmonte à la semaine qui a précédée les évènements. S'écouleront donc 7 jours durant lesquels votre périple vous conduira vers une des 4 fins potentielle. Chacun de vos choix compte et change le fil du récit. 

Vous endosserez le rôle de Cinders bien connue pour être une pauvrette endeuillée, malmenée par sa mégère de Maratre à la main et volonté de fer, épaulée par ses deux demies Soeurs Gloria & Sophia aux motivations partagées. 

Là où le ju est intelligent et ne se tourne pas seulement vers les demoiselles en quête d'amour et d'illusions c'est qu'il traite plus profondément de désarroi que tout un chacun peut connaître. Les personnages ont du charactère et ne sont pas tout blanc ou tout noir. Les fins aternatives peuvent justement conduire à découvrir les traits de chacun(e) ou même les voir changer complètement. 

Dans son intégralité ce jeu est charmant : que ce soit le design, les animations légères mais présentent (les expressions des visages, les mouvements délicats dans chaque scène qui permet que le cadre ne soit pas juste figé, la lumière qui s'oriente d'un protagoniste à l'autre pour illustrer qui parle), la musique que je trouve tout simplement divine. Même l'animation du texte à quelque chose d'enchanteresque.  
J'ai été séduite du début à la fin et ne regrette en rien mon acquisition !

Il y a très peu de succès steam, ceux ci se débloquent surtout à la découverte des différentes fins. Mais une fois dénichés, ils apparaissent sur votre menu pour orner Cinders et son décors. (il existe un guide qui pourra vous guider)

Le jeu n'est disponible qu'en anglais mais il ne requiert pas un vocabulaire trop riche pour en saisir les trames principales. Je ne dis pas que quelques mots ne pourront vous échapper mais globalement ça ne freine en rien votre compréhension du texte. Il est clairement accessible et vaut le détour.

30542991.review:
[b]"Rook di goo, rook di goo! No blood's in the shoe. The shoe's not too tight, This bride is right!" - [i]Cinderella[/i], Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm[/b]

As the first of Moacube's visual novels, [i]Cinders[/i] is a roaring success both for its genre and as an example of literary deconstruction. I've been meaning to play this game for years, and now I did, I cannot stop myself from taking new playthroughs to unlock all ending variants, to see what else this game may have in store for me. This unconventional interpretation of the classical folktale [i]Cinderella[/i] breaks all stereotypes and social generalizations, presenting an in-depth analysis of all its characters and probable intervening dynamics. Kudos to the developer upfront!

At this point, everyone with a semi-European cultural understanding is familiar with the story of Cinderella. Poor, golden hearted young woman who is treated like a slave in her own home by her ambitious stepmother and evil stepsisters. All her kindness only meets with mistreatment until a fairy godmother appears to bless her with a magical dress, a pumpkin carriage and glass slippers to attend the ball of the Prince. There, she is to steal Prince's heart with a glance and become the queen of the kingdom after a short pursuit involving those glass slippers. There, happily ever after, right? Nope, not so much. The original story was a brutal one compared to the Disney-fied version anyhow, and with [i]Cinders[/i] now, we are in for a more realistic version of the old fairytale.

Here, our protagonist' conditions are more or less the same with the original story. Her father has passed away, and now she is living with her stepmother and two stepsisters, whom treat her little better than a servant. She wishes to change her life, take the control of her future and decide the outcome of her own story though, rather than waiting for magic to happen! Sure, waiting for magic to happen is still our option, but just one of our options nonetheless. We are to live through a week of Cinders to witness the events just before the guard captain of his majesty knocks on our door. What happened to present such a necessity? Now, that is gonna be our choice. We will create a Cinders of our own. We'll make various choices, pick how to act towards whom and what to pursue in the way we chose. Eventually, we will meet one of the various endings appropriate for our personality.

In this glamorous visual novel, every single choice sincerely matters. Our actions determine our romance option - yup, we don't have to go happily ever after with the prince - , our character and eventually our own ending. Every single character involving - whether their role in the original story were small or grand - are reimagined into actual people, with their own personalities, background and aspirations. Did you ever think why the stepmother treated Cinderella the way she did? Just because she was evil? Or did you ever take a second glance at the captain of the guards? Why the fairy actually aided our girl the way she did? Because that's what fairies are supposed to do? Definitely not! Here, you are presented with a decent analysis of the story, stripped away from its embellishment and take a realistic approach to the situation, wrapped in genuine medieval context. The result is an incredible story with layers of characterization and perfect narrative with philosophical value.

The display is topnotch. All the artwork - both characters and the environment are fitting for a fairytale alright. Yet, this is not the strongest suit of the display. All character CG are presented in a way to maintain noteworthy body language and facial mimics, fortifying the narrative furthermore. Add a breathtaking soundtrack with various instrumental pieces of folk and epic music, and voila: here is a display environment you wouldn't grow tired of playing over and over again.

Now, I've already noted that endings are various. There are mainly 4 endings: one fairytale, one lady of the house, one “whatever, I'm out of this place" and one "not so happy". All these endings carry their own varieties within themselves however. According to the romance you pursue, the way you treated people and the amount of information you managed to gather by the end, you'll get a different variety of these endings. Every one of them can be tracked and re-read in the menu too.

At the end, [i]Cinders[/i] is one of the most imaginative, deep and successfully displayed visual novels that I've ever played. Even if you are not a fan of the genre, you may enjoy this one thanks to its narrative quality, depth and even sense of humor! At this point, I'll be looking forward for any VN that Moacube would throw my way. Enjoy!

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

30519629.review:
Do you want to pay money for a game with an underlying narrative about how abusers are kinda right and abuse victims should feel bad for taking appropriate action?  No amount of witty dialogue could cover up the inherently bad-- and at times disturbing-- game writing.  
The game promised to add character depth to a familiar story, and it did-- to a point.  The stepsisters have a dynamic consistent with being raised by a manipulative, abusive mother who plays them against each other.  Lady Carmosa, the stepmother, is emotionally abusive in a realistic way.  Like many abusive people, she makes sure to micromanage the people that she's abusing, put them down, and try tell them constantly that they need her to treat them this way because of how pitiful/stupid/etc. they are.  Cinders mentions in the dialogue that she believes that Lady Carmosa is capable of killing, and it's implied in Carmosa's dailogue that she may have killed her second husband, so she represents a physical danger as well.
There's a point in the dialogue where Cinders is speaking to someone who knew her late mother.  It has already been established that her stepmother is abusive.  Cinders explains that she believes that she-- not her stepmother-- is the legal inheritor of the family estates.  I chose the option for wanting to get an attorney to get my house back.  Mom's friend promptly gave me a guilt trip about the "consequences" of such a harsh act when my stepmother was just keeping the family fortune together.  You know, the family fortune that wasn't even legally hers that she's only using to benefit herself.  Given the more realistic take on abuse dynamics that the writers had so far, I figured that this was intentional.  Abuse victims often hear similar things from third parties about why their husband/parent/etc. isn't such a bad person and they should be grateful.  I waited for the protagonist to have an opportunity to confront this clearly inappropriate behaviour.
Nope.  Wasn't happening.
Every time the option for getting an attorney to get my (expletive) house back came up, I clicked it.  Every time, I got an NPC guilt trip and dialogue to make sure that I knew that-- although there are officially no wrong choices in this game-- I had made a wrong choice.  Bad, BAD player wanting people to get stolen property back from their abuser through appropriate legal channels.  How could I!  No matter how many times you choose that option, you will not have the opportunity to seek legal assistance to get the family house which you believe you're the legal inheritor of back.  There's also this little bit of talking to herself that Cinders has about how she's materially better off than most of the women in town so maybe she should be grateful for the life that her stepmother has given her.  You know, because if an abusive person takes our stuff we should be grateful to the abuser for what they've deigned to give us.
I played through the game just to be sure that there wasn't, you know, some upcoming branch in which the game would deal with the mess it made.  Nope.  It's sure as hell not getting a second play through.

30302446.review:
As established in earlier reviews, the world is beautiful; an appropriate art style and score. I appreciated that it focuses on the consequences of your character's developing personality, which you decide through dialogue and action choices, instead of focusing narrowly on the expected romantic relationship with "Cinderella's" prince. 

Some previous reviews criticized how the game punishes you monotonously for choosing "the wrong" character development choices. However, with that in mind, I noticed that the very 1st scene of the game, which foreshadows later events, hints at your win objective: your characters wonders if having a better relationship with the others in her life and making more empathetic yet pragmatic choices would have been better for her in the long-run. So, it's insinuated that the game will reward you for exploring her curiosity; punishing you when you're too romantic or too prejudiced. 

But, there are issues with the game. It's fair for some to be disappointed that the game doesn't have good and bad ending for all the possible character arcs--romantic, headstrong, or pragmatic--when it invests so much in immersing you in the world and having you feel like you are the protagonist. It feels like the game is attacking you; not just the character you created. Also, if you have little tolerance for it, the overt callbacks to the original fairy tale by the protagonist and morality play can feel like it's hitting you over the head mercilessly. But, if you come in wanting what the adventure offers, it's good at what it intended to do.  

I based this review off of Dizzi's gameplay. If you want to see it, you can [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfxgFtsTqegNhQ2txcPF2-uAqgxsZd_ee]check it out here[/url]. Be warned, though; spoilers ahead!

29392202.review:
Having played Cinders for more than 40 hours (guess I was really that into the game lol), I had the chance to unlock all the trophies and possible variants. I wanted to do so before posting my review of Cinders, as I usually like to complete a game as much as I can before I write a review. XD

Anyway, as a fan of visual novel games, I'll be writing this review from that perspective. Without a doubt, Cinders is one of the best VNs I've had a chance of playing and this isn't an exaggeration. Upon starting a game, the first thing that one would notice right away is the art. It's absolutely beautiful, as though it came straight out of classic paintings. The art is different from those in other VNs in that it doesn't adopt the anime-style but because of the nature of the story, I believe it was a wise decision to steer away from the norm. The music as well was quite beautiful and I felt that it did fit for most of the characters. I only wish there had been a jukebox feature in the menu so players could have a chance to listen to various music pieces away from playing the game itself.

What ends up sealing the deal for me, though, is the story. A VN must have an engaging story that I feel as though I can immerse myself in. It takes the classic story of Cinderella but adds a new twist to it. The protagonist, Cinders, doesn't have to be the helpless girl abused by her stepmother and stepsisters. The player can make decisions which shape Cinders' personality so she can range anywhere from being naive to cunning to rebellious. I loved the various branches that the games takes the player through so there are so many possible paths that one can take.

If there are any negatives, though, I'd say that there were a few typos here and there. I noticed a few grammar errors as well as some inconsistencies between using the American and British version of English words but honestly, these negatives are so minor. Although it certainly couldn't hurt to have the mistakes polished a bit, Cinders is such a beautiful, wonderful game itself that I can overlook them.

I'm happy to see that Steam has made such a wonderful VN available to its community and I hope to see many more games from MoaCube in the future. ^^

29344836.review:
Overall, Cinders was a joy to play. Some loveable characters, incredible art, charming music, and a fun retelling of Cinderella.

Game Elements: First and foremost, Cinders is a game. It offers many choices to influence the outcome of the game, and the outcomes themselves are varied enough to offer plenty incentive for multiple playthroughs. The skip mode is nicely implemented, as it stops automatically on text you haven't seen before. However, it doesn't really do anything unique for its genre.

Story and characters: It's good, but not great. Some fantastic character development with the sisters, but the love interests and the stepmother could use work. 
---------------Spoilers Ahead!
Carmosa, the stepmother, as you could imagine, treats Cinders deplorably, but we aren't provided with much of a motive as to why she acts this way. Yes, Cinders is not a biological daughter, but that does not preclude Carmosa from treating Cinders with respect. What's more obnoxious about this is that the game writing hints to the player that we should understand Carmosa's actions and respect her for it! It's little things, however, that make this a contradictory stance for the game: Carmosa could have fed her daughters smaller portions of dinner rather than feeding Cinders cold scraps; Carmosa's daughters could wear cheaper dresses so Cinders could wear something other than rags. It does not make sense for Cinders to respect Carmosa in this game unless she forgets the way Carmosa has treated her, and so the Carmosa as advisor ending makes no sense.
Gloria and Sophie, however, are excellent characters with natural growth through the course of the game. Gloria is seemingly cruel but just trying to live up to her mother by copying her, and in the way loses herself; Sophie is bitter and cynical because Gloria and her mother constantly criticize her and so her self esteem is ruined. Cinders has the option to help both of them grow in the game by encouraging Gloria to explore her interests and encouraging Sophie to be proud of her intelligence and intellectualism. I was also impressed by their complex relationship with Carmosa, since they loved her for what she's done for them (climbing the social ladder so they could have a better life), but they also resent her for not letting them to be free to do as they wish. It culminates in the Grand Ball, where Sophie ultimately decides she doesn't want what her mother wants for her, and Gloria doesn't know if she wants it, either.
Now the love interests. Let's start with Tobias, the childhood friend. He's got plenty of enjoyable one-liners and pleasant dialogue, should you interact with him. However, I never learn to trust him quite as much as Cinders does in his romance route. He puts his business ethics before Cinders's trust, worrying that she might ruin his reputation as a merchant. This is not a good start to a loving, trusting relationship. He wants to run away with Cinders in order to help her out in the traveler arc, but it would have been nice for his character development if we knew of some reason that he would want to run away from it all, much as Cinders wanted to run away in the Perrault traveler route. Maybe Tobias couldn't stand living in his hometown anymore; maybe he's actually not as honest as he appears, and he has some shady business he's running away from. I think my favorite route for him is Cinders as a noblewoman that marries her, as it seems totally believable that he would lend her a lot of money for social events and later marry her since they're in the same town. I do not like him as a lover to Queen Cinders, but that's because I'm trying to piece how they would stay in contact at court before he becomes a count.
Oh, Perrault. So many conflicting feelings. My absolute favorite ending is Perrault as the lover to the Machiavellian Queen Cinders, as it is incredibly believable that she would continue to see him after she becomes queen. He's an interesting character, indecisive on whether he likes killing and duty, but he would be improved by being more human and less tropey. I believe the true happy ending is Cinders adventuring with Perrault, btw ;)
And the Prince. So much could have happened! He was a good character with lots of potential! But then he focused on Cinders's looks at the ball... I would've liked to see him spy on her after the ball to determine if she was truly smart, if he was so committed to personality. He just needed more. And he doesn't deserve any ending where he isn't happy. He has to have at least a few flaws!
I think the rest of the cast is sufficiently likeable, with the exception of Shady Character. He baffles me. Where'd he come from?
And finally, we have.... Cinders!! I love that she's so moldable depending on the player's actions. She can be aggressive and a trail-blazer, or she can be docile and simple. And the text is sufficiently clear that I know the outcome of my actions on Cinders's personality before they're revealed to me. A+.
-----End Spoilers----
Overall, Story is 7/10, and Characters are 6/10. There's a bit too much going on in plot and not enough going on in character reasoning/development for why they act the way they act.

Visuals and Sound
This is where the game shines. The art style is stunning! The characters are all beautiful, and the landscapes are all engrossing. For the average person, there's not much more to ask for. Now, from the perspective of an artist, there is more that could go into the art design. The characters suffer from what I like to call "Same Face Syndrome": they all have the same face and differ in how they dress. What if Perrault had a hooked nose? Or Sophie's lips were super thin and had no cupid's bow? This isn't a huge deal, but it is something that I would like to see addressed in future releases. And for a bonus: Tobias's left hand looks super weird. 
The soundtrack is really fun and fitting, but there could be more sound effects to provide immersion.
Overall, Visuals are 8.5/10 and Sound is 7/10.

Enjoyment
Despite its flaws, it's still a very enjoyable game and a gem in the visual novel genre. I went and replayed it for all the different endings! I'd give it a total 7/10.
