28777264.review:
I came away from this game irritated and insulted. It's preachy, pretentious, and worst of all, it's bad at it. The art is gorgeous, and the level of polish makes this game a pleasure to look at, but the writing is absolutely awful:

Every character speaks with the same tone, style and vocabularly--a flat, boring style that is NOT fun to read. 

What's worse, though, is that the majority of the characters spend the entire game spewing faux-philosophical thoughts, narrating their own motivations and introspection, and reminding each other that everyone should have compassion because everyone else has problems too. 

[i]What's worse than that, though,[/i] is that the writer treats the player like an idiot, and spells out everything--and I do mean [i]everything[/i]--over and over again. There were at least 10 different times that the game reminded me that the stepmother has had it rough and deserves a little credit. There is not a single thing that the game lets you figure out for yourself, or at the very least, muse over for a bit before the game reveals it to you. The game actually starts by telling you that the stepmother and stepsisters aren't all that bad and that you need to have compassion for them--something that the player should have been able to figure out for him- or her-self.

As a huge fan of visual novels, I bought this game with the intention of playing it through multiple times to explore all the possible endings--but after suffering through it once, I'm never going to touch it again. Don't waste your money.

28109259.review:
I enjoyed this game and got a number of hours out of it between multiple ending playthroughs (free flow and some with a guide to finish a few missed options).  My one caveat is that you should snag this game on sale or as part of a bundle, as I'm not sure most people will find it justifies its full price.

First, you should know that this game is a lot of reading relative to the interaction time.  As the game warns you about in the begining, this is more like a book where you can make some choices to change the ending, rather than a typical point-n-click story where you are making choices constantly.  Luckily, it has a very nice "fast forward" option for skipping dialgoue you've already seen on playthroughs, which is something that is lacking in many similar games and is amazingly wonderful if you're hunting down other endings.

I like the concept of this game; building my own Cinders' personality and making my own choices and creating my own ending.  I also liked the take on the stepsisters as more than just evil sadists, and actually was fond of Sophie in particular.  It is a nice retake on a fairy tale in a less black & white perspective, especially since you can deivate significantly from the classic tale by making Cinders "bad" or reject the prince, etc.

The art is also beautiful, although I wish there had been more than a few backdrops, and a few characters whose faces and arms where animated.  I do like that there was some movement and facial expression over static art, just to keep things interesting through a lot of dialgoues boxes with otherwise identical visuals.  But like anything good, I want more than just a small taste of it!

The dialgue can be repetative, cliche, and predictible, but I didn't think it was totally awful (there was even a joke about the Captain's belts that genuinely made me laugh out loud).  Could it have been better?  Sure.  Did I find it turn me off from the game?  Nah.  Another review also complained that the writing was too blatant and the foreshadowing too obvious, but I find this preferrable in these types of games, otherwise it is too challenging and uninuititive to guide the story in the direction you desire.  While the choices are not always clear how they will affect the ending and you don't always get exactly what you were aiming for in this game, some opacity makes the gameplay more interesting.  There is a fine balance and I think the game gets it decently well.

The one change I would have made to this game would have been to add more frequent interactions with more choices.  They could have been additional conversation selections that were meaningless as far as the outcomes were concerned but valuable in terms of increasing replayability and creating more dynamic character personalities.  I think adding a number of trivial dialogue choices in between the "important" decisions would make players feel more engaged, break up the large amounts of reading, and make Cinders feel more realistic to each individual's vision of her.  There are already a huge amount of possibilities in terms of the endings, so I'm hesitant to wishlist for anything that increases those, but it would have been nice to have more options to influence the fates of more people in more ways.

Overall, I quite liked this game and am glad I bought and played it.  It might not be the most amazing game ever but it was some hours of enjoyment, which is all I wanted or expected out of it.

27903102.review:
Cinders is one of my all-time favorites.  I've played it a few times over the past couple years - whenever I feel like being whisked away into this magical, yet very realistic, fairytale world, and it never fails to make me smile.  It's always the first game I recommend to my friends that like choice driven VNs or fairytales.

The scenes are beautifully drawn in a sort of pastel style with vibrant colors to help set the mood.  The music is good too and very immersive.  Most importantly, the story is well-written.  The language can be a bit over-wrought at times, but that just adds to the old fairytale/literature feel.

There are quite a few ways the story can go, depending on your choices, and it's not always clear which choice made the diffference, but that's part of the charm for me.  It's not necessarily about where you wind up (it's definitely possible to get an unsatisfying ending), but about the journey of how you got there.  Each time I play, I feel like I learn something new about the characters and the world.  There were actually whole storylines I didn't even know existed on my first playthrough that made it pretty fun to play again.  Most of the characters are pretty intricate and more than willing to give you their soliliquy on life if you prod them the right way... or offer you a brutally scathing retort if you don't.  A few of them are really funny too!  Best of all, Cinders, herself, is a pretty relatable and empowering character with her own quirks and insecurities.  I could definitely see myself in her shoes (or glass slippers) if I lived in her fairy world.  Thanks to this game, I can imagine that I really am for a little while.

26698278.review:
[h1]Hoş Bir Sürpriz[/h1]

Normalde, visual novel türünde oyunları sevmem. Oynanış mekaniği diye bir şey olmaması, tek yapılanın sadece metin okumak olması ve bu tür oyunların ekserisinin şahsen itici bulduğum Japon çizim/hikaye/tepkiler/underage gibi elementlerden olması, bende visual novela karşı büyük bir hoşnutsuzluk oluşturdu. Ve gerçeği söylemek gerekirse bu tutumum baki kalacak.

Bu sebepten dolayı, aslında Cinders'i beğeneceğimi sanmıyordum. Hatta nasıl ve ne zaman, hangi kafayla aldığımı da hatırlamıyorum. Fakat ilginçtir ki, Cinders fena bir oyun değil. Tabii, hala visual novel türünün oynanış kaburgasızlığı var, fakat yine de çizimleri renkli ve canlı, hentai ögeler barındırmıyor ve herkesin bildiği Sindirella masalını farklı bir şekilde ele alıyor.

Oyunun görselliği ve seçimlerinize göre dallanıp budaklanan bol sonuçlu hikayesi benim için en önemli artıları. Karakterler de pek bir derinlik yok şaşırtmayan bir şekilde, çoğunun davranış örgüleri ve kişilikleri açık. Yine de oyundaki her karakterin bir mücadelesi/çatışması var, kendiyle veya başkasıyla, ve tasarımları başarısız değil. Müzikler hatırladığım kadarıyla fena değil. Diyaloglar, eh. Yine o her bir halta yorum yapan ve zaten görülür olan durumları özetlemeye bayılan bir diyalog/karakter sistemi hissediliyor. Ahım şahım değil yani, yavan. You had one job be abi...

Seçimlere ayrıdan bir parantez açayım: oyunun en büyük artısı. Oyunda yaptığınız şeylerin oyun sonunu bu kadar etkilemesi gayet hoş olmuş. Sanırım yirmiye yakın farklı son var. Oyunu bitirdikten sonra merak edip okumuştum bazılarını. 

[h1]Özet ve Son Karar[/h1]

[b]Şayet, ve bu büyük bir şayet,[/b] visual novel oyunlarına ilginiz varsa, Cinders'ı tecrübe etmenizi öneririm. Çizimleri hoş, hikaye farklı şekillerde gelişebiliyor, tekrar oynanabilirliği yüksek ve karakterler/konuşmalar da fena değil. Ben bu janraya fazlasıyla uzak biri olarak, bu oyundan hoşnut kaldığımı söyleyebilirim. Ha, gidip başka bir visual novel filan oynayacak bir gaz vermedi, ama en azından kötü zaman da geçirmedim. 

[list]
    [*]Uzak dur
    [*][b][i]Çok büyük indirimdeyse/oyuna ilgin çok büyükse[/i][/b] ✔
    [*]İndirim beklenebilir/ilgini çekiyorsa kaçırma
    [*]Her oyuncu oynamalı
    [*]Başyapıt
[/list]

26368045.review:
An excellent VN, don't regret buying this at all. Just overall great execution, artwork, characters and storyline.

Despite being built upon the old fairy tale, Cinders really went past the original in terms of storyline and setting (won't spoil it), I feel- while still being very faithful to the setting of the original, I feel. Or rather, Cinders established a believeable universe in which Cinderella would have occured, explained and went into detail on the otherwise normally supporting characters (the stepmother and sisters, the prince, the fairy godmother(s)), making them all not just believeable but very real and alive in the story itself. For such a short average playthrough (guesstimating 2~ hrs on the first run) everything really just fit in place so well.

The characters, as mentioned already, are exceptional. Even the typical villain (the stepmother and sisters) has complex motivations or reasoning- not to say they are morally ambiguous as I feel is a common flaw in such themes, but that their origins, their personal feelings whether right or wrong, their ambitions, etc... drive them. They're humans and they're inherently flawed, I guess. It seems like you really can reason, if you pursue it far enough, with any of them, really- even befriend them and mend the relationship. And the controlling family dynamic and how it affected each sister I also found a really unique take on such an environment. I found myself not really hating anyone in particular, [i]eventually.[/i]

All in all:

+Excellent storyline and believeable, relateable characters. Just really well put together overall
+Great art, personally enjoy the stylistic approach taken as well if that counts for anything
+Some decent form of replayablity, I feel- I think I'll be coming back to this one

Can't really think of any negatives to this. The pricetag (20$CAD) is pretty high for such a game, despite how well it's put together, perhaps.

26111697.review:
Is the classic Cinderella a victim of her stepmother and step sisters, or is she a victim of her own inability to change her circumstances? Do faries steal people's agency in a literary sense as well as literally? Is the self immutable, or can it change in response to circumstance? If it changes in order to better survive difficult times, is that an improvement, or the shameful death of something precious? Is a democratic government merely an excuse for people to lie to each other all the time? 

In addition to offering a chance to ponder the above questions, Cinders is a fantastic exploration of both self-empowerment and self-destructive tendencies within the context of a classic fairy tale. It also has some fantastically witty lines and some good meditations on romantic love and its strengths and limitations.  

For its message of empowerment, ambtitous themes, and fascinating characters, 10/10, cannot wait to play again.

I played through once, and have not yet decided whether it's worth the effort to do it again for the sake of finding other story variations. I would recommend it at $5, but not the $10 that I paid.

[*]и текстовые эффеты, иммитирующие темп речи и интонацию.
[/list]

Минусы:

25433317.review:
This game is incredible. If you love twisted fairy tales and the ability to manipulate the story, then you'll have a ton of fun with it. The story is such a good twist on the original and you have so many opportunities to change the outcome. I still haven't been able to figure out how to achieve all the endings, although if you play enough of it you'll see easily how the decisions diverge. I wish there were a complete walkthrough for each of the endings, but unfortunately I haven't found one yet. 

Before I bought the game I had no idea just how many endings there were; there are four main ways to end the story, but each one of those endings has four or five different endings as well. It's incredible how easy it is to get sucked into the game. And, fortunately, if you've encountered a line of conversation before, the game will let you skip all the dialogue until you hit something new. 

I love the art style and although there isn't any voice acting involved, the music is soothing (and can be turned off if you're not into it). The game developers have done a great job with the characters as well. Cinders herself can be incredibly devious or a pushover, depending on how you play her. 

All in all, an excellent way to spend many, many hours on your computer.

Wow... I bought this game a while ago and only recently got around to playing and have to say i'm impressed. Having played copious amounts of VNs in the past (and present, they are a guilty pleasure of mine, afterall), I was surprised with how many options and endings were available to the player to affect the story. Usually there are a couple of options with some rather than others being the more 'important' ones that affect the story but here, it seems as if almost every option branches the story in another direction. You help guide Cinders and with the choices you pick, her personality changes and so does the outcomeof the tale. The 'evil' stepmother and stepsisters aren't as black or white in this case - everyone has a reason for doing what they do and the characters are humanized. You're forced to take into account not only the actions but the setting the characters are in; whether they do things considered good or bad, most of the times they're just trying to do the best they can do in that situation.

Okay so basically what I'm trying to say is yes you should get the game and try it out because its worth the money. They put a lot of time and efforst into this one and it shows :)

Cinders is a visually appealing modern take on the Cinderella fairytale.  It did a great job of including occasional social commentary without detracting from the overall flow of the narrative.  I enjoy anime but hadn't delved into visual novels, until Cinders.  The slight changes in movement and expressions of the character portraits, music, and the overall storyline kept me engaged, without feeling like I was trudging through a glorified illustrated book.  The decisions that you make actually change the storyline and the interactions between characters.  Choices in the game also come up often enough that you’re not reading for extended periods of time and sitting as a passive observer, but rather as an active participant.  Although the option to “fast forward” through text made completing alternate storylines a relatively quick process, I would have preferred the option to “skip” text and scenes entirely or the ability to move directly to bookmarked decision points. 

I consider this a fun and endearing introduction to visual novels because of the familiar, yet engaging theme.  It also created a spark of interest in other visual novels. The inclusion and portrayal of characters derived from African/Afro-Caribbean  traditions and beliefs was a very pleasant suprise.

24114892.review:
Cinders is a visual novel that is based on the fairy tale we all know, Cinderella, and I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of playing it. It's certainly no fabricated Disney setup though, as it has a more mature take on the story, some of which involve politics, psychological wounds, social discrimination, etc., but still retains the light-hearted feeling of fantasy from the original.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] The lovely, rustic art style, one of the first things to catch my attention: a right mix of dark and heavy, as well as stunning, colorful fairy tale scenery, which creates the perfect atmosphere for the story's theme
[*] The music is a masterpiece, from the sound effects to the background music that plays on each scene: lovely to listen to, yet not too overwhelming to distract you from your immersion
[*] Beautiful dialogue you wouldn't want to skip, with just enough suspense that can't make you stop reading
[*] The subtle animations, from the way the flowers would sway to the wind, etc
[*] A handful of amazing characters, well-written so you could actually sympathize with them, even the antagonists
[*] The variety of choices given to you, and the many, multiple endings you could choose to unfold with them: high replay value because of this, you could be a charming and innocent Cinders in one playthrough, and a deviously cunning one the next
[*] As with most VNs, involves romance options, but is written so well that it makes said options neither a necessity nor the main driving force of the story, but only as a 'side quest', and focuses more on heavier themes
[*] More than enough endings: you are left with four main endings, as well as many different sub-endings under each one
[*] Provides you with a hefty amount of hours to complete, or read from start to end
[*] Has a feature wherein you can skip through parts you have already read, to explore the different outcomes
[*] Easy to obtain achievements, got to 100% in no time
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Some of the dialogues are... For lack of a better term, awkward, and a few moments are too cringe-worthy cliché
[*] Lack of, or rushed character development: pacing feels off somehow, and it gives you a feeling that everything is happening too fast
[*] Typos in some dialogues
[/list]

This is the first visual novel I have played, finished to the very end and tried to get all possible endings I can. For people like me who are not that fond of anime VNs, and have a particular interest in similar themes, this game is definitely worth trying out. Can't wait to try out other VNs from MoaCube~

[h1]Overall Rating:[/h1]
8.5/10

Of course, it also depends on how you go about it - just because you try doesn’t mean you’ll succeed! 22250810.review:
This is a gorgeous, polished, thoughtfully-written visual novel that walks a nice middle ground as far as complexity goes - it's hard to "break" the narrative with one's choices (which is a problem a lot of otome games run into), but there are still lots of those choices and you can really see their impact on how the game unfolds and resolves.  

The endings are broken down into four main categories, with a lot of room for variation within those categories that makes for a high replay value.  Art is unique and beautiful, and the writing is consistently clever.  Pacing is excellent.  I finished my first playthrough in 2-3 hours, which felt just about right, given how many more times I want to go through it.

Really my only disappointments were the lack of F/F romance potential, particularly in a so wonderfully lady-centric game (forget the prince; I wanted to marry the fairy!), and what felt like some untapped narrative potential regarding one of the major story branches (without getting into spoilers, there's a lot of vague but explicitly called-out foreboding around that branch, implying interesting and not necessarily pleasant consequences that don't seem to show up in the actual endings).

22060253.review:
TL;DR: Beautiful game with a lot of player agency but not labeled correctly by the devs and 'flat' romances.

I really liked playing this game and I would warmly recommend it to any VN fans out there. That's not to say it's without faults but it's a very good take on the genre.

Pros:
- The artwork. It's gorgeous, it's original, it's great.
- Player agency. You have choices and they matter (GASP!). You get to see the consequences of some choices soon after making them, other later on but it's so rewarding to have a story that can go in so many different directions.
- Endings. No 'secret' or 'true' ending, your choices can lead to an ending that fully reflects the kind of character you wanted Cinder to be and that ending can be good or bad depending on your actions.
- The NPCs. They are more than one-trick ponies whose one-sided personality is the end-all be-all of whom they are.
- Info. The information you get from certain actions can be used later on, if you choose, leading to a lot of branching in how you play.

Cons:
- The labels. It's NOT an RPG. Labeling it as such is misleading to people who are looking for RPGs in the store. It's a visual novel, do not be fooled. (Yes, you take on the 'role' of Cinder but then EVERY game is an RPG and the label loses its meaning, not helping anyone anymore.)
- The romance. If you're gonna add romance options, make them good. There could have been more depth to this aspect of the game as a lot of it was not as fleshed out as I could have wished.
- The variation. With so much variations there's a lot of aspects of the story that are simply introduced and then not really explored, this is a real shame as some of them are really interesting.

In conclusion: I don't have a lot of gripes with this game as I truly enjoyed it. There's a lot of consideration for player input and choices and if you enjoy visual novels, I definitely think you'll like this.

21077260.review:
Based on the ancient fairy tale of Cinderella, the visual novel [i]Cinders[/i] tells a similar story of everybody's favourite soot-covered girl struggling under the oppressive yoke of her step-family. Playing as Cinders, who got this nickname from her deceased father because of her flaming red hair, you finally get to have a hand in your own fate. Develop your own personality, from kind and smart to Machiavellian and downright evil. Will you try to understand your stepmother and stepsisters and repair your relationship with them or are you looking to give them a taste of their own medicine? Will you pursue the handsome prince, flirt with your childhood friend, or even charm the captain of the guard?

Or perhaps romance is not what you're looking for, and you'd rather re-acquire your family's estate... Anything is possible!

[h1][b]Pros[/b][/h1]
+ Gorgeous, magical art, especially the backgrounds
+ Lovely soundtrack
+ Choices affect your personality values, which creates a branching path to MANY different endings
+ Goes against fairy tale tropes & provides a new spin on Cinderella

[h1][b]Cons[/b][/h1]
- Preachy, lifeless, and unnecessarily long dialogue
- Very few save points considering the amount of choices
- Characters' eye animation sometimes heads straight into uncanny valley
- Some story elements are never fully resolved (i.e., The Fairy and the Shady Character)

I enjoyed [i]Cinders[/i] mostly because of the excellent combination of fantastic fairy tale feel (thanks to the gorgeous art) and the fact that Cinders herself had a tremendous amount of agency. Sometimes I felt like the game tried too hard to go against fairy tale tropes, creating preachy dialogue with especially the stepsisters in trying to show their point of view in their difficult household. The same goes for the concept of agency and power -- I don't think I can count the amount of times that "independent woman" was brought up.

If you like Western-style visual novels and fairy tales, then you're likely to enjoy this one! Just keep in mind that it can come across as a little preachy, but the huge amount of endings and pretty art makes up for it.

21028608.review:
Cinders are basically just Cinderella story that you know it well.

Mean Cind that want her house back from Stepmother, Or just a normal girl who just show up at the ballroom and Prince just like her opinion and want her to be the Queen. 

It never be like an old Cinderella that we know, Anastasia and Drizella are not be like the old one, here they more friendly and reasonable, which I really love it. 

There nothing more than just a book story that need you to read, but the good one is that you can choose what in the end that you would like it to be. 

Recommend, if you love Cinderella story :)

20903664.review:
Keeping in mind what this game is, it's beautiful, intriguing and keeps you wondering what would happen if you chose any other path, which is what games like this are supposed to do as that keeps you playing them.

Now, if you like freedom of movement, freedom of character development or freedom of customizing your experience, I can't recommend that you would enjoy this game. Cinders, for all the beauty and wonder of her world, is very firmly set in it. Despite getting to know all these little things about the world around Cinders, at her core she stays the same person, which is a little difficult to believe considering how drasticly each of her paths can change. 

Not only is Cinders fairly grounded in her ways, but also everyone around her. Not to spoil anything, but none of your decisions are going to make anything truly amazing or drastic happen. You will simply be able to examine this story from all possible angles and, as was common with oral-passed stories in the past, determine which moral or characteristic is more prominant in the success or failure of the story.

It's fun if you like that sort of thing. I do.

20882685.review:
Pros:
- As everyone has said before me: the art is beautiful. The music is pretty good too. No problems on the technical side-- skipping and transitions always went smoothly. 
- The characters are very fleshed out and put together well. I found the step-sisters to be my favorite. The love interests are rather stereotypical, but not always predictable. 
- The story is fun and intriguing. Definitely a mature telling of the Cinderella story. I feel like you could enjoy it regarless of interests and gender (which I mention as several guys seem to worried this game is too "girly"). 
- Decent length. Can't remember my exact time of my first run, but I think it was somewhere around 4 hours or more (my on-record-hours are off by several). 

Neutral
- Many of the game's choices change character personality rather than storyline-- which is an interesting decision. The result is different flavoring in the endings. 
- The replay-ablity is decent. I'd say you could get 3 pretty solid play-throughs before too much of it starts to repeat. 
- Writting is better than it is worse. Though some converstations are too drawn out (see below). 

Cons:
- Cinder's posture is TERRIBLE. Stand up straight, gurl. I caNNOT STAND IT.
- As mentioned by several others, the game does get preachy at times in conversation, making it feel tedious. However, I can appreciate WHY I assume the creators have done this-- it's a genuine attempt to create character and relationships. Is it successsful? Not completely, but most VNs I've played just throw you headfirst into relationships with little to no development; so I'm glad they tried, even if it didn't totally work out that way. 

All-in-all: A good visual novel. The asking price is a tad steep, but I wouldn't hestitate to pick it up if it goes on a sale.

Note: recent edit done to fix spelling errors.

20798827.review:
Overall this is a great game!
[*]The artwork and overall style is fantastic.
[*]The interface is simple and intuitive.
[*]The sound effects were above average. I muted the music, but tend to do so in every game. Other sounds were excellent with the exception of the tavern. It is a rather short loop, and becomes repetitive.
[*]Your first game can take ~3 hours to complete. Subsequent games go quickly as the Ctrl key allows portions of text you've previously read to be skipped.

My two complaints:
[*]One - The writing. 
The writing is not bad, it just needs improvement. There are quite a few typos; you can easily discern what is meant, but they are a distraction. To the developer's credit, there is a discussion in the community hub where typos can be submitted, but this game was released a few years ago, and more than enough typos remain to make me wonder if a patch was ever applied. Where is the game text stored? I'll edit typos for a reasonable rate.

With typos removed, I find the readability level directed towards younger readers. You won't find many big words, or stretch your vocabulary. This is not bad, as it makes for an easy read, and likely makes for a larger audience. I would have preferred the text to be geared more towards an adult audience.

[*]Two – Some of the Choices / Paths
One that stands out to me is Cinders relationship with her younger sister Sophia. In one playthrough I felt I made some real progress in rebuilding a normal relationship between the two. But come the next morning when Sophia actively seeks to spend time with me, I have to tell her that I was planning on some alone time in town; maybe next time kid?... We were just getting somewhere!

[h1]First time ever: I expected so much more at that price.[/h1]

[i]"Now that you've bought it, we can honestly say: Don't expect much. These are still-images that change every umpteenth line of fontsize 38 text. We show only 1 or 2 lines at a time, so get ready to speedclick through a tale that might appeal to you, if you're an adult lady whose life still teen-sucks. Wuhu, take that, Disnee!"[/i]

It's not what the first message ingame said, but pretty close. I'm all up for "visual novels" and challenging the whole "gaming"-koncept, expanding it with new and throughly enjoyable ideas like Dear Esther, Gone Home, that stuff ... but come on, these slideshows are what we call "comics", and books ultimately beat 'em hard in visuals when you're supposed to take in so much text anyway.

Luckily Steam fully understood how many paperback classics the price of this game could have bought me, and refunded. Let me know when it's around €2 and I might enjoy clicking through a glacial-speed slideshow for more than 10 minutes. Sure, it may be your thing. Could be mine too, but not at this price or featuring current theme.

This is not about what is affordable to me. This is about classification, and principle stops me from enjoying a €17 flipthrough-book. I write my few reviews with - tiny - friend list ind mind, and they shouldn't spend that kind of money on this either, so there we go.

19671486.review:
Cinders is a visual novel solid in every way and that's rare.

First of all, it's gorgeous. I'm not teaching anything if you already glanced at the screenshots but it needs to be said because it's actually pretty important. Many visual novels have a cheap look, and I personally feel that it has a really negative impact on my enjoyment of the story. In Cinders you want to move forwards just to see the next picture.

But it's not just window dressing either. The writing is also great, and I do mean it. All the characters and situations are believable, the premise was enough to hook me in and the world is an interesting place to discover. It's nice for a change to play something that you never did before when many visual novels are pretty iterative.

Finally, the choices. Nothing to write home about, but they are there and they are significant. I actually prefer something that really allows me to put my mark on the story rather than thousands of endings for the sake of it. It's good and having the opportunity to twist such an iconic story is a great pleasure.

To conclude, this game is amazing. Maybe even one of those niche games good enough to be enjoyed by someone who usually don't play them.
A little caveat nonetheless: despite all my praises, I think the price is too steep. Wait for a sale.

19510324.review:

Cons:

Is it worth the price:

Is it worth buyig:
+ yes... if you like visual novels (there is reading involved and all the fun comes from it)

19501571.review:
Это такая новомодная тенденция - смотреть на всеми любимые добрые сказки под совершенно другим углом. Особенно хорошо их сейчас пропихивают в киноиндустрии: "Охотники на ведьм" (2013) - про Гензеля и Гретель, которые ходят в клёвых кожаных костюмах и пачками укладывают разную нечисть; французский вариант "Красавицы и Чудовища" (2014) - бредовая сказка для взрослых; "Красная Шапочка" (2011) - вариация на тему "Сумерек" для озабоченной подростковой аудитории; боевик с элементами романтики "Белоснежка и Охотник" (2012) - как очаровашка Тор мог влюбиться в Беллу Свон, ну как?! Или та же "Золушка" (2015) с размышлизмами на тему жизни и смерти, неграми при дворе короля и очень своеобразной Феей-крёстной Хеленой Бонем Картер. Последний фильм, кстати, неоднократно мной вспоминался, пока я играла в данную версию "Золушки". У меня даже возникли подозрения, что авторы фильма вполне могли быть знакомы с этой игрой. Или это наш с вами современный уклад жизни теперь диктует сказкам скатываться в бытовуху, в которой нет места расовой дискриминации? Я не удивлюсь, если какой-нибудь американский режиссёр снимет "Сказку о мёртвой царевне" и среди семи богатырей обязательно отыщется азиат или афроамериканец. Я не расист, просто те, кто занимаются кастингом, не думают головой.

Что в этой игре может понравиться:
- графика/рисовка;
- музыка;
- нестандартный взгляд на всем с детства знакомую "Золушку";
- отомэ-вариация на тему "Зачем мне Принц, когда вокруг есть другие интересные мужчины?"
- тонны текста и выбор различных вариантов ответов;
- довольно красивый значок для профиля в Стиме, если вы охотитесь за карточками.

Графика в этой игре очень красивая и лично мне напоминает многочисленные квесты по поиску предметов, где хочется потыкать курсором в каждый куст, чтобы найти очередную загадку или локацию для поиска. Персонажи здесь довольно забавные. Женщины явно делали ботокс в губы. Принц Василий похож на монгола, а друг детства Тобиас - это какой-то Шалтай-Болтай. =D

Музыка хорошая. Некоторые композиции у меня ассоциировалась с уровнем Wonderland из игры Kingdom Hearts. А тема Феи так вообще что-то из Heroes of Might and Magic IV. В общем, с этим всё отлично.

Далее о том, что в этой игре может НЕ понравиться:
- нестандартный взгляд на всем с детства знакомую "Золушку";
- тонны текста и выбор различных вариантов ответов.

Да, плюсы переползают в минусы. Если вы не готовы к тому, что Золушка в этой игре может выступать в роли убийцы, мошенницы или блудницы, то лучше не беритесь за прохождение. Это не всем привычная сказка про Золушку, а какая-то чернуха. Главная героиня может отказаться от магии и волшебства, взяв судьбу под свой контроль, и ковать "счастье" собственными руками. Но здесь нужно дать авторам игры подзатыльник. Когда Золушка находит способ изменить свою жизнь к лучшему и это не "Даже если вам немного за 30, есть надежда выйти замуж на принца", девушка всё равно идёт на бал к Принцу! В игре кучу раз вам придётся делать выбор, и вы всё равно попадёте на этот чёртов бал. Почему? Да потому что Золушка как в песне у Zera: 

Нубка юбку натянула и уселась на траву. 
Закричала: "Я крутая! Посмотрите на меня!
Как же смотрится красиво на мне блестящая фигня!"

Последняя строчка чуть-чуть изменена, но факт остаётся фактом: в некоторых прохождениях Золушка идёт на бал просто для того, чтобы утереть нос сводным сёстрам и мачехе! Брависсимо.

本来想多玩几条线做个全成就的，但是剧情实在太冗长了，莫名其妙的选项也很多所以就这么着吧。

Cinders是一款改编自《灰姑娘》的视觉小说，相较于原作显得更加现实。本作中Cinders的母亲是一位手段比后母更高明、更会做人的人，Cinders遗传了她的优点，拥有掌控自己人生的能力和野心，最终选择走上王座或者除掉后母夺回家产，当然了，也可以选择（携手帅哥城管）远离家乡开启新的生活，或者一步之差为自己的选择付出代价，葬身地牢。游戏一共分为以上四种路线，玩家如果想达成特定路线就需要提早准备好选择倾向了。
画面：乍看还不错，细看除了插画画风的那几张以外都挺偷工减料的  6.5/10
配乐：会玩这款游戏受了大量评测里的“BGM好棒”影响但其实只是平平  6.5/10
选择性：比较丰富，尽管很多都是累赘  6.8/10
剧情：对话拖沓，剧情冗长，毫无亮点  6/10
总评：我是抱着看黑化和反转的心态玩下去的……结果就这么平平淡淡地结束了？  6/10

18689413.review:
Cinders is a very beautiful game, probably one of the most gorgeous games I have played.  It is not only an amazing visual novel with a dark, mature take on the story of Cinderella, but also contains elements of dating sims and roleplay as well.  I really enjoyed the wide ranges of decisions to make along with the variations of multiple endings.  Not to mention the dialogue is very well written, with very deep philosophical tones and also some comical moments as well - especially with a few fourth wall breakings.  All in all, this is a very good visual novel and certainly won't be disappointing.

Pros:
- Beautiful artwork - every character and background is absolutely gorgeous
- Nice subtle animation - it really helps bring the novel to life and draws more attention 
- Amazing soundtrack - I would purchase the soundtrack if they offered it 
- Interesting Storyline - has a nice, dark twist to Cinderella while also including elements such as identity, self-empowerment, independence, decisions, and more.  It's not only a story, it's plenty of food for thought as well.
- Variety of Decisions - there are so many to make and it really helps drive the story in different directions, which makes things all the more interesting.
- Great Character Development - all of the characters have a distinct appearance and personality and it really shows not only visually, but in their dialogue.  It's fascinating to get to know them and it also helps them feel very real.  This part was truly amazing.
- Replay Value - you get different achievements from different decisions and different endings, so there's a nice challenge

Cons:
- The dialogue can get a little repetitive at some points.  There's some parts where a character will emphasize something and then it will be emphasized again and again.  This part makes the subject they're emphasizing a little too drawn out.  
- Replay Value can feel tedious if already played through trying to get the achievements.  
- Personally, I wish it was longer.  

Overall, this is a very charming visual novel with many great qualities in terms of aesthetic artwork, intriguing storyline, and heartfelt character development.

I keep playing because I do want to know how it turns out and how my choices change things but lord.  I feel like when I replay this with different choices it'll be about 75% shorter because of all the stuff I'll be fast forwarding through.

18598402.review:
I was surprised with how good the story ended up, compared with how much I dislike the source material. It made the story of Cinderealla actually make sense. However, I think the full price (around $20) is a bit steep because there is limited replayability, and the overall story is fairly short. But considering the quality of the game and not the price, I would say the game is a solid 8/10.

Pros:
+ Great story, and above average writing.
+ Memorable characters, each with their own agendas, problems, and personalities.

18566561.review:
Amazing game, and I say that as someone who doesn't normally play visual novels because: a) they are usually drawn in the style of anime, and b) they are usually dating sims -- I find neither of those two things particularly appealing. This game, however, is not even close to being a dating sim (although there are different romance options you can choose to pursue) and the art style is miles away from anime and very beautiful.

The story is a retelling of the Cinderella fairytale with a lot more depth, featuring well-rounded characters, complicated familial relations and meaningful choices. It emphasizes the extent to which characters' personal choices are limited by/the product of their circumstances and surroundings. The wicked stepmother and stepsisters are not simple archetypal chracters but complex figures with motivations and agendas that arise from their life circumstances. The main character Cinders, the young woman who lives as a servant in her own house, is trying to take destiny in her own hands and break free from her current circumstances, but cannot do so without outside help. The game makes a point: despite her desire to be independent and have agency, her available options are nevertheless to some extent the product of particular conditions that are outside of her influence (of her father marrying as he did, of her mother ensuring Cinders gets help when she needs it, etc). 

The writting is very good and the choices in the game are meaningful; I found replaying the game to explore different results very interesting. The first playthrough takes about 3 hours, while subsequent playthroughs can be made a lot shorter as there's an option to skip through dialogues that you've read in previous playthroughs. 

Definitely recommended for people who love good stories and don't mind reading a bunch.

18452468.review:
Cinders is very interesting take on the classic story everyone knows, and so far it is absolutely my favourite adaptation of the story. 

Have you ever wondered why the stepsisters and -mother are so mean? Well this game answers to that question, when you play it you will find more about 'the antagonists'. You may even end up sympathizing them when you know what are the motivations behind their actions, which you don't actually see much in some other Cinderella stories - where the step family is just mean because potatoes.
Also the art in this game is just amazing, backgrounds are like atmospheric paintings... character art is nice too but sometimes the anatomy is maybe a bit awkward. But that is just nitpicking.

[b](Small spoiler warning)[/b] Another thing what I liked about in the game is that it has few different endings, and none of them are actually truly happy endings... well maybe one could be counted as almost perfectly happy ending. But others, well, they are not actually that good when you think about them.[b](Spoiler end)[/b]

Overall, I do recommend you to play this game. It may not be very long, but at least to me it was nice experience. If you are fairytale lover like me, I am quite sure you will enjoy this game as well.

Western VN. The writing is terrible: none of the characters talk like real people; main character not only has no personality, but is bad at assuming the motivations of the player choices available (it sounds like someone is telling her what to do and feel through an earpiece, and she forgot to read the script); weak plot motivations. Also, for a game that seems to be trying to tout strong female characterization, the female characters in here sure are huge assholes. Not one of them is likable. 
Issues elsewhere include: only 8 save slots even though you get prompted for a choice every two minutes (filled all my saves in less than 20 minutes), protagonist's dialogue arbitrarily switches from outward conversation to internal narration with absolutely no visual or audio indicators, backgrounds have perspective completely wrong (for it to be right the camera POV would have to be at thigh-height, at least 15 meters away from the characters, which is absurd), no volume adjustment, only 3 text speed settings. 
The only good things about it are the menu and background animations, which are pretty great, but it's unfortunate that they're wasted on this game.

The art is unique and fitting for the darker tone, and the music is beautiful in every sense of the word.  There are different endings you can discover, and each can have different variations depending on your choices throughout the game.  While you can get through one telling in a rather short period of time, the depth, detail, and impact of choices makes replay-ability good for a few play-throughs. 18011298.review:
An awesome game! Probably the best graphic novel/dating sim that I've ever played. 

I like that all the characters in this game have depth, even the supposed villains. And while there's a number of people you can "date", you have to be very clear on your path with them to get the best endings. There are also paths where you don't end up with anyone at all. All of your actions really do have consequences. 

The game is extremely well made. The graphics are stunning and the background sounds work well. The game runs very smoothly and so far, every storyline I've played has been enjoyable. 

There were a few times in the game where I felt the dialogue got a bit preachy. The writers obviously really wanted to push the idea that Cinders was strong and independent, but at times it was like they were beating you over the head with it. Don't get me wrong, I love this game and I LOVE the fact that it actually has a strong female protagonist and that the goal of the game isn't necessarily to end up with a man. I think a little bit of subtlety would have gone a long way.

What an amazing game. Not sure I'm entirely qualified to write a review since this is the only visual novel I've played - but I love the game so much, I have to gush about it. Let's see:

Pros:
- Incredible soundtrack. It's too bad they don't have that as DLC because if they did, I'd buy it in a second.
- Lovely graphics. The artwork is gorgeous in a perfect fairytale way.
- Very interesting story. A good thing too if you're going to play over and over for multiple endings.
- Rich characters. Their dialog was well written and I cared alot about what happened to them.
- Choices really make a difference. The way the story flows is very much up to you. Choose wisely.

Cons:
- Some of the dialog between characters can get a bit preachy.
- As with most "choose your own adventures", they don't always give you the choices you'd like.

     All in all, if you have any interest in the Cinderella story or a well written book-like game with pleasing artwork and music, I highly recommend this. And with all the many ending variations, there's lots of replay value. I've 100%ed the achievements but there are still 2 endings I really want to see so I'm not done playing yet. What a great game!

Kopciuszek w zupełnie innym wydaniu. Zamiast jasno nakreślonego "zła i "dobra", skrajnie przerysowanych postaci, upiornych sióstr, macochy-potwora, kochanej wróżki oraz cudownego księcia, dostajemy coś zupełnie innego. Dostajemy bohaterów z krwi i kości, mających własną osobowość, własne przekonania, aspiracje, interesy, tajemnice oraz pragnienia. Każdego z nich można zrozumieć i polubić. Historia rozszczepia się w kierunku czterech rodzajów zakończeń, jednak do każdego z nich istnieje wiele wariantów (wpływ na nie mają m.in. osobowość Kopciuszka, podejmowane przez nią decyzje, jej wybranek czy relacje rodzinne). Wszystko to okraszone jest niezwykle piękną, jak na standardy visual novels, grafiką oraz nastrojową muzyką. Przez całą grę da się wyczuć iście magiczną atmosferę. 

Polecam każdemu fanowi visual novels, baśni oraz intrygujących historii i jeszcze bardziej intrygujących postaci.

A very well written take on the classic Cinderella tale. Part of what made the game for me was how three dimensional the characters are. In the original tale the step mother and sisters were such evil caricatures that they are as realistic as any pantomime villian (i.e not at all). In Cinders, while still mostly despicable, they are fleshed out and given realistic motivations for their actions and that helps the whole tale resonate much more. There are quite a few paths through based on what descisions you make during conversations so there is some replay value, though you will have to sit through quite a bit of the same text and dialogue if you wish to see them all, as often the variations aren't major until the end. All in all a fantastic visual novel with a story that will continually surprise you with the turns it takes while at the same time making you laugh with its witty dialogue and gentle pokes at traditional fairy tales.

Pros:
Excellent writing
Full of twists and surprises
Well realized characters
Awesome soundtrack
Multiple endings

Cons:
Getting all the endings can be a bit of a chore

16998127.review:
10/10

Everyone knows the story so it's unique in the way that you have have a vague understanding of what's to come and this has a big impact on how you play the game. I can't quite recall playing a adventure game before where you know already what is going to happen. End result is a surreal experience - It's like replaying a game you have already completed in your mind and then the end result and journey there is something entirely different. 

Nice details on the main characters are worthy of special praise: Stepmother and sisters being the best characters in awhile in just about any adventure game. Disney pictured them as monsters. This game gives them a much more humane form. 

High production values and good graphics and soundtrack ensures a smooth game experience. Multiple endings for replayability and you get a whole new perspective to the other main characters in the original fairy tale. 

Best in it's genre this far.

16994595.review:
There are very, very few games that ever make me want to say: "Even if you don't like or care about {X}, play this game anyway." As someone who thinks deeply about game mechanics and play styles, I understand not everyone will enjoy certain games.

That said: even if you don't like or care about visual novels, play this game anyway.

Cinders retells the fairy tale we are all familiar with -- and walks a fine line betwen the lighthearted enchanted Disney version or the dark, sadistic Brothers Grimm. Well rounded, fleshed out characters (even for the "evil" and minor characters) gives this a vibrant color and tone that is often missing, both from fairy tales or from games. Rather than giving certain endings an official seal of approval, Cinders uses this potential ambiguity to allow players to ask themselves what the "best" ending should look like.

All in all, this results in a thoughtful and "political" game -- not through design choices or the author's intent to make a specific statement, but merely by reflecting the player's choices back to them in a realistic and candid fashion.

16823595.review:
Cinders is a story that takes start on a classic fairytale, but quickly becomes something much more mature, realistic and interesting. It's a story about women, their choices, motives and personalities and how all this lead to very different lives and consequences. But more than that, it's a story about Cinders - smart, brave, kind and ambitious girl, who doesn't want to sit and wait for her happiness and prince who saves her, but rather takes her fate into her own hands. 
The game is really replaying and roleplaying - all your choices have their consequences that may not appear now, but take place later, when you almost forgot about them, so chose wisely. You have many possibilities to turn story in your favor, every ending has many variants and sometimes its change the tone of an ending completely. Your Cinders can be kind and modest, wise and bold, egoistic and rude - all this changes the story that you'll see. I really recomend you to try and play, especially if you fan of visual novels or choices and consequences games. Cinders really worth a shot. And it has marvellous strong female characters, something that we don't see often, sadly.

16820463.review:
The Quick: [h1]Became Clicker Heroes for me fast. Click, click, click.[/h1] 
[h1] Where's the perspective???? [/h1]

[*][b][u]Overall Ranking: 6/10[/u]

[u]DETAILED[/u]

[u]Pros[/u]:
+Visually looks appealing.

+A good amount of characters.

+4 different themed endings.

+ Nice color palettes.

+Characters fit in their environment stylistically.

+Appealing music.

+Sometimes more than two choices to go through.

+Some choices impact story well.

+Achievements easy to get.

+ Don't have to end up with the prince, can be with two other male characters.

+Have Cinder being  independent, endings.

+During Steam Sale, game was cheap.

+UI Design was nice.

+Liked the trophies that would appear in main screen.

+Can choose between the Fairy or Madam Ghede path.

+Like that Stepmom and sisters aren't always seen as bad, depending on path taken.

+Movement outside windows to give some life to setting.

+Nice texture

[u]Cons[/u]:
-  [h1]38 Variations of the 4 styled endings[/h1], which end up seeming repetitive except for the last few parts of that version of the story.

-Some character's[h1] body proportions seemed fairly off or disturbing[/h1]. (Prince's head to body ratio, "Shady Man's" thumbs are tremendously long.

-Clothing is weird on "Shady Man". Looks like it is really tight by his parts.

- Some character's [h1]body alignment is off[/h1]. Cinder's neck and some of chest is facing right, but then her lower torso is facing leftwards and then her lower clothing suggests she is to the right which makes for awkward twisting in the body. Many other characters have that issue.

- Background has[h1] no atmospheric perspective[/h1]. Everything looks sharp when farther away it shouldn't.

-Perspective is off. Things would be way too big if moved to where character is standing. 

- [h1]Not enough saves[/h1] for being a game with more then one styled ending. Usually with visual novels they have more saves then necessary but this one lacked!

- Cannot name saves to keep better track of what is what.

-Always have to go to the dang ball. I'm running away who cares!!

- After two playthroughs, story becomes bleh and nothing new or interesting to the plate. All stories still have same structure and path to go on regardless of ending you are choosing to go towards.

- Creepy eye movement from the Prince.

-Carmosa's folding her arms looks very off in perspective, her left arm is not done right.

- Needed more variation in poses. Only arm position or facial expression changed. Body stayed the same.

-[h1]NO SKIP BUTTON[/h1]. This was so annoying when trying to go back to get other endings.

-Regular price is so not worth it. Payed $9.99 during Steam Sale and that was more decent based off the issues this game has.

- Seems to drag in conversations where you don't get much say in.

[h1]Based off of more cons thans pros would not recommend. The art may seem pretty at first but after playing it for awhile you start  to see all the mishaps making it less appealing. Story became bland after a couple playthroughs and dialogue rarely changed. If you want to experience this yourself go ahead but it is not as enticing as it looked.[/h1]

16785229.review:
I waited for this game to go on sale because I think the price is a little ridiculous. But for $10? This game is definitely worth it.

The story and art are incredible to say the least. The many different paths and endings you can achieve give the game a high level of replayability, along with the the ever so hand "skip" button (which stops automatically whenever you encounter a new scene or piece of dialogue you haven't seen before.)

This is a visual novel where your choices really do matter. Every component of your relationships with other characters and personal character choices influence the ending you receive. My only complaint is that the price is a little steep, and I was lucky to have gotten this game while it was on sale.

10/10 I would reccomend this to all lovers of visual novels, fairy tales, and dark stories. This isn't your average fairy tale :)

16687156.review:
OVERALL - 8/10. 
First note this is after completing all paths, and alternate endings/etc. So this is a full review on the entire game and my personal opinion/s.

I'd suggest the game to others but I have played better VN's for the same price with artwork that was just as well done, which had voice acting and a longer story. Cinders feels short but it does have a good story/alternate endings.

Artwork - 9.5/10.

* Cinders' facial anatomy is uneven in an unnattractive way and some expressions make her eyes rotate which uh they don't do in real life. Also the prince has a lazy eye.

* Overall graphically the game looks great. It really does, it has a french painting type feel to the entire game, and it has wonderful coloring/shading [spoiler]Though the ballgowns were lazy recolorings with different lace/necklaces. Boring. Where's the creativity!?[/spoiler]

Story/Gameplay - 8/10. 

* The story does change depending on what choice you make, but without looking up the wikia page of Cinders, there's  no way of knowing what skill you gain or didn't gain by choosing that option. It isn't always obvious what the smart/bad/good choices were. 

* Having a meter on the left side of the page would be super helpful as there's a lot of unused space there. (Spoiler following.) [spoiler](Getting the "fair" queen ending especially, as well as the Machiavellic Queen endings. First playthrough I had the Evil queen four times before figuring out what I was doing wrong. :/ Not fun. It made things extremely frustrating for me. [/spoiler]

* Half point loss for me is lacking the ability to go back and see moments such as the (spoiler)[spoiler]Ball gowns and dancing with the prince at the end of the game.[/spoiler]. For me collecting the extra scenes/memories is half the fun in VN's. Cinders lacks this.

* Half point loss also goes to the fact that the game controls are NOT the same as -most- other VN's, Having skip be keybound to left CTRL is a major annoyance, as the windows key is right beside it for my computer. :/  plus due to the location of the windows key on a US based keyboard. left control is not optimal.[/spoiler]

Music - 6/10. 
* The music does not loop seamlessly and it is quite noticeable, not to mention there is NO IN GAME VOLUME ADJUSTMENT OPTION. The game's music by default is -too loud.- This game lacks voice acting, so I did expect more out of the music in the game. 

Possible Bugs and updates to think about? - 

* When in the options menu, right clicking in attempt to return back to the game. causes the screen resolution of the game in windowed mode to switch resolution, which might be intentional but is very annoying especially to those of us who play many other VN's and right click normally exits menus/enters them no matter which page you're on.

 * The steam overlay is missing the ability to resize itself to the size of the window, meaning that it's rendered entirely useless the user is playing in full screen, which some may do, but I personally dislike doing as I often have friends in other chat clients, and as such may need to alt-tab to a different window. There's a fix for this although I'm not sure how, I do know that it does resize in other games however.

* The text speed is uneven at times or lags and suddenly slingshot-text superspeeds across the UI screen, which made me skip several lines while on autoplay in Normal. AND I could not scroll back far enough to re-read/ There's no actual Script page with the full scene. As such - had I not already played Cinders once, I would have been entirely lost on the story. There's a limit to how fast a person can read, even on the Normal speed it would randomly speed up. Also the auto  play option did not last long enough/went past long paragraphy sentences in the same amount of time for a short sentence. Again made me miss some text. This isn't new to the steam release either. It's been there since I purchased the game originally. Pleeaaaase at the very least fix this.

* If you attempt to skip text by pressing control once or twice the dialogue box disappears entirely, which obviously skipping text so whatever. But - when doing so sometimes the UI text box would be -gone- which also made the text-skip for that part of the game super quick. Bug methinks.

---

As a final note:

I'd like to mention that the Cinders for letting older users get Cinders on Steam instead of having to repurchase. :) That is  awesome.

16495092.review:
Gorgeous VN, providing a nice variation from the mainly anime style VNs available. The character designs are beautiful, they are also pleasingly expressive for the amount of detail on each of them. (I'd gladly buy a poster of madame Ghede or the fairy to hang on my wall, if one were available :L) The backgrounds are wonderfully atmospheric, particularly around the fairies' lake, perfect for the fairytale story it's based on. The music also attributes to this atmosphere setting the tone for each scene.

The characters are enjoyable, the opportunity to work with Cinders' step-family was a nice variation to the original story. Cinders also stood out as she was a very likeable protagonist, with a lot of personality. 

The major con of this game is it's length, there are relatively few endings, it would have been nice to see more possible love interests/lifestyle paths for Cinders as a lot more of it is based on who is allied with her at the end and whether she is good, or bad. You can finish most, if not all, endings in one sitting, so it, unfortunately, has little replay value story-wise.

Overall, I'd recommend Cinders as a beautiful and atmospheric experience, utilising it's game qualities to enhance the events taking place. My only wish is that there were more events.

TLDR: atmospheric & beautiful art, with interesting characters, but is relatively short/has fewer endings than most other VNs.

16325413.review: A well-written, beautifully drawn, and gorgeously scored gem.  The characters are all multifaceted, and you genuinely root for all of them.  (Making the "evil stepsisters" sympathetic was an artful twist.)  This reminded me of why I love the visual novel genre, and what it can do.

16274120.review:
Cinders, a twist on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, is all about its characters. It has all the elements of Cinderella: A ball, a prince you can pursue, evil stepsisters and stepmother, and a fairy godmother. However, Cinders herself is a strong, optimistic, and self-reliant woman capable of taking her future into her own hands. Her stepsisters and stepmother are well developed characters that you can get to know and maybe even understand. The fairy godmother isn't perfect and neither is the prince. Add to that the Captain, the town witch, and Cinder's old friend the merchant, and you have a variety of extremely interesting characters with their own stories and complicated relations to you and each other. Throughout the game, your interactions with them and your decisions for Cinders helps her decide which path to freedom to take. Each broad ending has a variety of unique and lovely sub-types.

If this hasn't told you this game is worth playing, then add to that the lovely artwork with small background animations and very realistic and expressive character art, the beautiful music, and the tiny fact that the dialogue speed matches the speed of the character speaking. This last fact really helps you mentally hear how people are speaking. Honestly, it's as close as you can get to voice acting without actually having voice acting in it.

tl;dr Go play Cinders. It's amazing. 10/10

16254538.review: While there is an interesting story and beautiful art there aren't very many choices for the player to make. It feels like 75-85% of the time you are just clicking through dialogue that you have no control over and then suddenly the game is over. The game was alright and I'm sure the different endings will be interesting but considering how much the game costs and the lack of control you have over the story I wouldn't reccomend it.

16233194.review: Cinders is a choose your own adventure visual novel. It is a re-telling of the classic Cinderella story. The writing, artwork, music, sound effects and characters are all surprisingly well done. The gameplay is smooth and the dialog is entertaining and not boring, even though we all know the basis of the story. There are many decisions to make throughout, and each decision changes the story and leads to multiple endings. Not only are there multiple endings, but several variations of each ending, depending on the choices made. When re-playing to find alternate endings, you have options to skip dialog that was previously encountered. That was a great idea by the developer because having to click through all the dialog again would have been a drag. Overall this visual novel sets a high bar in the genre and I have no complaints. Recommended.

16202396.review:
This isn't your typical anime visual novel......and that is what makes this game fantastic!
Lovely visuals and pleasant music.
And the story...choices that you make through this game actually combine, giving you multiple (often surprising and shocking) endings. This isn't your usual Cinderella fairy tale...it can be very mature and often dark.
Your answers/choices make impact on lots of elements: what kind of person will Cinderella become (trust me, this Cinders can become anything: scary child that lives in her dreams; cold and calculative; seductive lady that wants everything...and everyone...and gets what she wants; a bad girl...in lot of ways), relationship with family (with surprising outcomes), her love life (and we are not talking just about the prince...), even how will she end her life (this game is not all about "living happily ever after", trust me)...
Story and characters itselves are well well written and shaped.

Overall, this is not just great visual novel, this a great game by itself.

15864739.review:
Cinders is a pretty fantastic visual novel, full of strong female characters and decisions that have consequences. It's a darker, more mature take on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, but with some clever twists. The artwork and music are really gorgeous and add a lot to the story. It's also worth noting that this is one of the rare visual novels that uses an art style other than anime.

The game's a bit short and even going back and playing several endings won't take much longer than a few hours. Unfortunately, there isn't a lot of replay value. While there are a lot of different endings in the game, things become a little tedious after you've played through a couple of times. Other than achievement hunting, there's not much payoff for getting all the endings.

Even though it's brief, the story and characters are engaging and it's an enjoyable experience while it lasts. It's also a visual novel that's a bit heavier on the novel part than straight-up dating sims; several different pairings can occur, but the focus isn't entirely on romance.

I personally think that the $20 price tag is a little steep for such a short game though, so look for sales or bundle deals.

15864532.review: I loved this game! The art was gorgeous and it felt like my decisions mattered. I've ran into too many story games that fall short in both areas. Great job!

14759410.review:
I originally had this game on my wishlist based on the art style alone. Turns out, it's a re-imagining of the tale of Cinderella. And it is a visual novel, where your choices have an actual impact on the story.

[b]Graphics / art - 5/10[/b]
Let me get this out of the way since this is what first pulled me in. Mmmm ... not that impressive at the end of the day. Most of the characters look a little weird, and there's just not much animation. I know it's a visual novel, but it feels like they could have done a little more. So it's not bad, just not quite up to its potential in this area.

[b]Story / characters - 8/10[/b]
The story itself is slightly adapted, and I have to say the developers did a great job. The wicked stepmother and the two evil stepsisters are actual characters with personalities, and through the story you can understand some of the reasons why they behave as they do. Truly a tremendous spin on a stale old tale.

The developers also get into why there is a ball, which is pretty interesting.

The most annoying character is probably Cinders herself. In some ways she behaves like any normal person in a shitty situation would. However, other times she's a bit whiny and preachy.

My favorite character was actually the stepmother. She's less of a demon when you get to know her reasoning and motivations. And her drive is impressive.

The side characters beyond the main ones (Cinders and her step-family being the core characters), are less interesting, and it seems like there are some interesting mysteries into their backgrounds that unfortunately don't get fleshed out. Like what the relationship is between Cinder's mother and some of the other side characters. What happened to Cinder's mother?

[b]Gameplay - 10/10[/b]
As with most visual novels, it's mostly reading. However, at key points you get to make decisions. I wish I had read about the game before playing to better appreciate the impact of decisions. It would have let me know how important it is to use all of your (I think) 10 save slots so that you don't have to restart the story from the beginning to find all the endings.

Basically, you can be good, neutral or evil based on your decisions. And your decisions impact your route to the ball, which suitor you end up with, and whether you're even happy at the end. I overwrote a lot of my old saves as I went along, so I was really limited in my endings. However, I think there are a total of about 12 variations.

Pretty incredible, eh? The game itself isn't amazing, but when you realize how the developers freshened up the source material, you can't help but be impressed!

8/10

14396805.review:
With some regret, I have to say that I do not recommend this game. 

I really wanted to like this game; the premise was promising and the art style is beautiful (though the scenes are limited; don't expect much variety). 

This visual novel has the makings of a great novel--great artwork, interesting characters, a wealth of different options, the ability to skip scenes easily on a second playthrough (viewing only the new content you haven't seen before), and most importantly to me, your choices change the outcome of your story. Every choice matters. 

The only real fault I had with this game was the atrocious writing. It was painful--unrealistic language, blatant foreshadowing, laughable and sometimes downright confusing conversations. The makers of this game went so far into making sure that the player was aware of the nuances of each character that they beat you over the head with them, and then beat the horse you rode in on too. I like subtle, complex characterization, and character growth should be something developed over time and with a touch more realism. Rather than creating nuanced dialogue the game screams it at you, and then has the main character repeat it to herself in her alone time just to make sure you didn't misunderstand anything.

I paid $4 for this game via Humble Bundle , and spend roughly 3 hours doing two playthroughs (with numerous bouts of getting up for pizza and tea). If I had paid $20 via steam, I suspect my review would be that much more vitriolic...if you go to the effort of making a well-crafted game, you should spend some time crafting the text with the same dexterity shown elsewhere.

I have played games similar to this one so when I first saw it I was very excited! I have tried it and I have to say that I'm slightly disapointed with the experience. I mean, don't get me wrong, the game itself is quite nice, it has wonderful artwork, the characters and scenario are very well made but, to me, it just lacks a few touches that would make it even more special. 

One of the things that really bothered me right from the start was the awful sound you get when the text is being shown. After awhile it almost feels like needles in your brain! Since I couldn't take it I turned it off and to my surprise there wasn't a single alternative other than pure silence. Like I mentioned before, I have played similar games and most of them have someone reading the lines, which makes it less boring and easy on the eyes. I mean, lets face it, having to read several lines from beginning to end can get extremely boring after awhile. Especially since most people will have to do multiple playthroughs and the game doesn't offer a proper way of skipping the lines you already read. Yes, you have the option to re-read the previous line but you can't skip to the next. You can click several times to make the text appear a bit faster but imagine doing that, pretty much, from beginning to end...

I believe the game should have other small touches such as background noises. For example, when we have the outdoor scenes it would be nice to have the sound of birds, wind, etc; when attending the ball at the palace we could have music playing, people talking or when Cinders is at home, in her room the sound of the fire in the fireplace. 14377515.review:
[i]Cinders[/i] is a colorful, emotionally-vibrant Visual Novel, starring Cinders, a wide-eyed, fiery-red, female protagonist. Cinders is about to embark on a journey—a journey of choices. The story will most certainly bring to memory another classical tale of romance, intrigue, betrayal & the pursuit of happiness.

Choices are the core gameplay element in [i]Cinders[/i]. The choices you make really do matter. The world will unfold around you according to the decisions you make—and you will always be aware of how they affect what occurs next. The gameplay mechanic for this is that a budding branch will emerge from the corner of the screen to denote an event playing out that has been mitigated by previous decisions. This conspires to make a living world, where you’re not an observer but a participant.

While choices are at the core of [i]Cinders[/i], they dance around the diverse characters. The characters are complex, disturbed, scarred, & much more. None of the characters are simply good or bad. They reach out and play with your emotions as if they were flesh & blood. 

The artwork in [i]Cinders[/i] is colorful & vibrant. You’ll oftentimes find yourself looking at the background scenery, to catch a look at the swaying shrubbery, or the flickering fire. The soundtrack is diverse & emotionally fitting to each scene as it unfolds. It’s easy to get lost in the simple background melodies.

[i]Cinders[/i] has a full screen option, with the option to choose screen ratio. The game looked great on a 30” screen at a 16:10 ratio playing in full screen mode.

In conclusion, [i]Cinders[/i] is loosely based on one of the classics, & most certainly worth a look if you’re interested in the Visual Novel genre. It will make your heart tingle & your nerves race as you take an emotional journey with Cinders.

9/10

Now, this is a fantastic game. What really stood out for me was the stunning art. The visuals are very well-done and they really help set the tone for Cinders. The characters felt alive; they're not shallow like the ones in the fairy tale. A lot of thought had definitely been put into the dialogues as they're engaging and witty at times. They really speak to the characters. The storyline follows the generic one of the Cinderella, with many interesting variations thrown in to make Cinders stand on its own and speak to the players.

There are four endings to the game, with some variations which are shaped by your decisions. In theory, Cinders has very high replayability due to the sheer number of choices and branches that it has. However, I lost interest before discovering all the ending variations. For one, I found the variations to be minor. Two, it was tedious to have to go through the same events and dialogues over and over again, even in fast-forward. After a certain point, it was just not worth the effort to go through the motions to see how else the conclusions could vary, especially since I was quite satisfied with the ones I did get already. 

I think a contributing factor to my eventual lost of interest is that I feel the choices I made reflected my values and overall outlook. You could find that some decisions really speak to you and there's just no desire to choose the alternatives; it's likely that you'll like the first ending you got the most. And that's the case for me.

14196030.review:
Overall rating: 9.5/10

To anyone who enjoys visual novels/choose your own adventure stories, I cannot recommend this game highly enough.

Story:
In terms of story, they did an excellent job weaving a narrative that places the story of Cinderella in a context that makes sense. Your stepmother and stepsisters are more than just villians, they are characters/people with lives and motivations that you can choose to understand/learn about or not. The other characters you meet in the story also have histories and distinct personalites. Cinders' relationships with other characters are also affected by choices you make. References to the past/history are very fluidly revealed in conversations with people. The game does not just dump a bunch of backstory on you for seemingly no reason. The game is also filled with some excellent dry humor, and amusing banter.

Gameplay:
If there is a game where literally every choice has an impact, big or small, this is it. There are multiple personality types for Cinders (I've discovered three) that are shaped by the choices you make. Cinders' personality type will affect certain dialogues, the availability of certain choices, and the consequences of certain choices. Certain scenes or dialogues with other characters will also change depending on previous choices you have made. There are multiple endings with several variants of each, and it does not come down to one or two "big choices" at the end or anything simple like that. Whether or not you succeed in achieving your desired specific ending is dependent upon the cumulative effects of choices you have made throughout the game. That being said, the replay value is very high, in my opinion. I have enjoyed replaying it to find the different endings/variants and get the achievements.

The only downsides in terms of gameplay are minor, but still exist. There is no good "rewind" function. If you missed a line, or want to return to read an earlier part of the conversation, you are limited. The game is divided into "scenes" probably for program/design sake. However, you cannot scroll further back than the first line of your current "scene." This could be several lines back, or just one. Fast-forward is sub-optimal. It just cycles through dialogue at rapid speed until you come to a scene/line you haven't viewed or a choice. You can't "skip to next scene" or "skip to next choice" which is disappointing on replays.

Presentation:
The artwork is pretty, from the character portraits to the backgrounds and facial expressions change over the course of conversations. The music is good, and fits the scenes quite well. My only gripe was that introducing a character meant briefly interrupting a scene to focus on the character on a leafy-flower design background and a change in music that felt a little out of place.

Pros:
+ Story
+ Characters
+ Artwork
+ Choices & Consequences
+ Replay Value

Cons:
- Limited/sub-optimal fast-forward and rewind functions
- Awkward character "introductions"
